content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Awesome open-world FPS.  A little rough around the edges and glitchy, but still a great game.  The game is over 7 years old, so it is a little dated as well.  The game takes place in "The Zone", referring to the uninhabitable area surrounding the Chernobyl nuclear power station.  You start the game as a man with amnesia.  Throughout the game, you try to piece together who you are.  Within The Zone, there are anomalies, bandits, mutants, and treasure.  You have a lot of choice in the game.   You can use something loud like an AK-47 or you can try and be stealthy. The only real problem I have with this game (besides the glitches and other bugs) is that it is very difficult at the start.  You start with a pistol and some food, so it is difficult to kill the bandits/soldiers who have much better weapons than you at the start of the game. Overall, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is a flawed yet fun open-world FPS.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												The first STALKER game, and the one that kicked off an amazing franchise. SOC is quite rough, but well worth playing through.SOC is a fairly non-linear FPS with light RPG elements. RPG elements are mostly in the form of an inventory system and NPCs to converse with. Character progression is purely in the form of equipment, as you progress through the game you will find better weapons, outfits and artifacts (radioactive items that grant small defensive bonuses). There are plenty of side quests, mostly taking the form of repetitive fetch quests, but sometimes more complex.What really sets the STALKER series apart from most games is the amazing atmosphere. The game has an extremely bleak and depressing atmosphere. The game is set in the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone, and contains many real world locations that the developers painstakingly researched. SOC has an extremely active modding community, I would highly recommend skipping the highly publicised "Complete" mod and instead playing with ZRP for your first playthrough. After a first playthrough with ZRP it might be worth trying out the Oblivion Lost or AMK mods, which make quite drastic changes to the gameplay.

number of helpful: 18 of 19 people (95%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												DISCLAIMER: I am reviewing the completely vanilla, unmodded version of this game. I have heard there are many great mods, but my first playthrough was without any. This game really was a joy to play. From the awesome world and the terrifying encounters,  to the unintentionally hilarious vodka overdoses and the cheeki breeki-ing, I really ♥♥♥♥ing liked it. The game has been compared to Fallout and other RPG post-apocalyptic survival games, but I like to classify it as it's own type of game. A game where the unknown frightens you and you are left fighting for survival where it seems everything is out to get you. The specifics of what I liked and disliked are recorded in the following paragraphs.THINGS I LIKED:1.First of all, this game has something really special, and equally hard to describe. To put it simply, the world seems to be alive in a way I haven't felt in many other games. Let me paint a picture: You come back to an outpost after a hard day of fighting bizzare mutations and equally bizzare bandits and sit down the fire by a complete stranger playing the guitar. As night falls, you enjoy a diet sausage and a bottle of vodka around the open fire in silence, treasuring these moments of peace. This is what I really love about this game. That is about the only way I can describe it. The feel of the world is Just sublme.2. The core gameplay feels very solid. Guns kill suprisingly quickly and gunfights feel very tense, as if you are actually fighting for your life.3. The story is presented in a unique and fascinating way.  You must learn about your world and what is happening through the PDAs of dead stalkers and dialogue with living ones. The story is subtle and leaves a lot up to speculation, in a way similar to Dark Souls, which I absolutely love.4. Lastly, the game runs like a pro. Kind of a big deal if your computer is utter♥♥♥♥♥♥ like mine. That's what I liked, now here are the things that I kind of disliked (nit-picking ahead)DISLIKES:1. There are a few bugs, which can be expected from a game of this age, although I have read that the majority of them can be fixed with various mods.2. Guns in the beginning are extremely inaccurate. This isn't necissarilly a con, but expect to be missing about 90% of your shots from anywhere over 20 meters until you find something that isn't a Kalashnikov variant.3. The graphics aren't great. I say this, but the dull graphics kind of add to the game's gloomy mood. Again, if they aren't for you, there are a plethora of mods.4. I like to pretend that the multiplayer doesn't exist.CONSENSUS: I love this game. It is one of the most unique experiences that I have been a part of in a while. Whilethere are a few problems, I plan on playing through again with one of the many overhaul mods, which I heard can provied an even better experience. Will definately be checking out Call of Pripyat and Clear Sky.NOTE: Helps if you speak Russian. Not a must, but adds to the immersion and authenticity.

												An absolute must-play for anyone into first-person shooters.Despite its notorious amount of bugs (which are easily fixed with well-known mods and community patches for the game), the mechanics of this game and its rather considerable difficulty (at least when compared to other first-person shooters) make it very entertaining to play through. Don't come into this game expecting some masterfully crafted plot or anything of the sort. The story does just its job of giving you a reason to move forward, while also staying out of the way so you can take in everything the Zone has to offer.No game has come close to being as immersive and having such a good atmosphere as the STALKER games.

You can even drive old Russian vehicles that give you a steady dose of Radiation! So good hunting Stalker!

number of helpful: 40 of 59 people (68%) found this review helpful14 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Идеи игрового мира S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Тень Чернобыля базируются на повести братьев Стругацких «Пикник на обочине», снятого по её мотивам фильма режиссёра Андрея Тарковского «Сталкер», а также на реальной зоне отчуждения Чернобыльской АЭС[8]. Разработчики рассматривали идею создания игры на основе зоны отчуждения ещё задолго до начала разработки S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Однако мысль о создании продукта, основанного на смешении «Пикника на обочине», сталкерства и зоны отчуждения возникла накануне второго официального анонса игры в марте 2002 года.Изначально концепция данного проекта, имевшего тогда рабочее название «Oblivion Lost», никак не относилась к Чернобылю. Как подтверждают сами разработчики, его сюжет был схож с сюжетом фильма «Звёздные врата». Действие игры должно было происходить в будущем — во время галактических империй, с тысячами населённых планет и разумных рас. По сюжету, путешествие между планетами осуществляется с помощью порталов — недавнего научного открытия. Игрок и его группа являются частью авангарда и играют роль первопроходцев — первыми встречаются с новыми, неизвестными до этого и, возможно, представляющими опасность, мирами. В игре должны были присутствовать постройки ацтеков. Данная идея успела перейти на стадию разработки — сотрудники компании создали играбельный билд «первой» Oblivion Lost.Однако концепция игры, схожая со «Звёздными вратами», показалась разработчикам вторичной. В рамках создания такой игры требовалась проработка множества виртуальных миров, что небольшой фирме было не по силам. Команда поняла, что создание «ультрареалистичного» игрового мира будет для неё более подходящей задачей, нежели создание фантастического. Кроме того, разработчики хотели найти уникальную для игровой индустрии идею, чтобы встать в один ряд с лучшими разработчиками уже после своего первого большого проекта, и понимали, что их текущая идея, повторяющая уже созданные вещи, таким требованиям не соответствует. 29 марта 2002 года они съездили на экскурсию в зону отчуждения. Это явилось последним шагом к решению о полной замене концепции: она стала напрямую относиться к Чернобыльской АЭС и местности вокруг неё.

												This game is like Fallout's drunk Russian cousin. It is difficult, frustrating, and scary. It's also incredibly fun, well-made, and addictive. number of helpful: 13 of 13 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												This is the first game i've sat and researched in 7 years and this is why...Usually when I play games I switch off, hit keys/buttons and just zone out the day, s.t.a.l.k.e.r shadow of chernobyl does the absolute opposite. I have learned in my limited amount of playing that complacency equals death, there is no relaxing, there is no zoning out there is only concentration.The atmosphere of the game, sound engineering, tonality of the setting and the ambience really give off that feeling that you aren't in a playground, you are in a world where one wrong corner and one stray bullet can stop you dead.The best way the developers could get that message across to the player is when you first step out of sids bunker, there's a random series of beeps, the wind blows and sometimes a cat wails in what is probably its last moments. The wind blows emptily through the tree's in the distance you can hear the droning about the zone being a deathtrap and a first time player can feel extremely out of their depth, confused and lost. That feeling of dread and confusion will stick to you throughout the game, that feeling is your survival instincts, a gut feeling you never really understood until now.The first thing many players including myself learn is that you aren't  a walking death machine, you are frail and the zone let's you know that with a swift death, a death you will repeatedly see until the game crushes your precogniscent mindset on how you play shooters. You will reach a point where you will be angry and the game feels too hard and unfair but deep down, you know it was your own error that killed you so many times.Learn the mantra: "The zone gives with one hand and can take with the other."Next comes your rebirth, you become cautious of everything, every noise, every voice, bang, scream, growl and even your own footsteps. You learn the cordon like the back of your hand, you study where the dogs go and how the boars attack, you watch the military patrol, you'll probably get brave and after earning enough seeking artifacts you'll bribe the guard to let you through the railway bridge. You memorize every stash you find, you break every box, you loot everything and you drag yourself, heavy footed to the newbie village, down into sids bunker and you unload your winnings.Then, your second lesson begins; you aren't a mule, you cannot carry every gun in the eventuality you will need it, you don't need 30 cans of meat or 50 medkits, you will never need to carry every AK47 you find. Yes I know i've played fallout and yes it kills me to leave stacks of guns on the roadside. But you need to train that out of yourself, if not, you will die and lose it all and it's that crushing choice between leaving a nice heavy suit at the bottom of a ladder or suffer a grim death at the jaws of a pack of dogs that will be your making.Learn the mantra: "Greed Kills"The third lesson is one that takes time to practice and patience. The zone does not work to your advantage, you are a guest in the zone and everything there is designed to kill, you will become aware that even the air itself can kill you. One thing that terrified me was anomalies, I initially thought after studying the cordon that anomalies were a semi-visible entity that could be easily avoided, how wrong was I when I walked straight into an electro anomaly, and a burner, and vortex anomalies. The third lesson took time and plenty of error to get right, bolts are key in passing through new areas safely pay attention to the beeping you hear that's your only way of knowing they're nearby, that and always staying mindful of the other noises around you.Learn the mantra: "My ears precede my eyes"The forth lesson in one that you should have been practising since day one in the zone and that's foreplanning; ensuring you have the ample equipment for the job. The landscape of each mission can vary massivley so preplan your travel. Read about the areas online, ask the stalkers about the surrounding areas, learn all you can, because even with that knowledge you can still be taken by suprise.Learn the mantra: "the enemy of my enemy will also kill me...unless I know they both will already"The fifth and final lesson is discipline, knowing your environs is all well and good but understanding that the previous four lessons are not merely one time tips but a collective of constants is key. Repeating the same processes over and over becomes almost habit the act of stop, look, listen, wait becomes second nature, this is when you begin to fully understand the game you play with the zone. The game isn't to win and kill everything, it isn't even to be the best, it's about being the one who knows when to pick their moments, the right equipment, the right time of day, the right moment to move from building to building.S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl isn't your average game, it's a lesson in life in a way, it's a mantra in itself that if you give up, you'll only feel sour about doing so, if you fail repeatedly then the way you're doing it is wrong and most of all if you relax for just one second you could get your face inverted by a bandit with a sawnoff.

number of helpful: 13 of 13 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												This is one of the best FPS games I have ever played, would it be blasphemy to put it up besides Half-Life and Grand Theft Auto? No, I think not. This game is literally ground-breaking even compared to the games of today, 2015.S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl has some of the best AI that you could ask for, only the players interaction and the pathfinding is scripted. All encounters with the enemy are purely random depending on which side is luckiest or which side the player chose to join or fight.The story is kind of vague but the cutscenes are amazing. There are 7 different endings, 2 depending on choices and 5 depending on stats. The story, though vague, is Really good. The story starts after a second nuclear disaster of Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant in Ukraine, you wake up in a small village with no memory of what has happened or who you are, except you have been given a task on your PDA to "Kill Strelok" or "Стрелок" which is Russian for Gunslinger. from there, it's pretty much freeroam with a few main-objectives which leads to a conclusion. The game is as long as you want it to be, depending on which missions you partake in and how much gear you need (or THINK you need) for the next objective.I played this game with the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. COMPLETE 2009 mod.All in all, this is a really awesome experience. My rating would be 9/10 (with above mod)The only thing that could make it better, would be a deeper story... Well, not deeper, but better explained. But that's why I'm going to play the prequel now!-For the right ending, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Call of Pripyat takes place after Strelok destroys the C-Consciousness.I won't really call this a spoiler, more of a guideline.Chronological Order:1: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Shadow of Chernobyl (2007)2: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Clear Sky (Prequel) (2008)3: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Call of Pripyat (Sequel) (2010)

content:
Posted: January 30
												Oh my!This is my first ever review.I havent done a review for my favourite game which is Skyrim but this game is amazing.I was looking for some good survival and horror games and after the metro series(Which were amazing) i wasnt sure if this would satisfy me.GraphicsAs far as graphics goes i dont mind at all.As long as the gameplay or the story are good graphics dont matter that match but it looks good enough.StoryNow on to the story i havent finished the game yet so i dont know where it leads.You basically wake up in a banker and you are told to kill a mysterious guy.GameplayBut enough of that.The 10/10 of this game is the gameplay and the atmoshere.This game is really a great challenge and i am playing on Stalker difficulty(normal)out of the 4 difficulties it has and i have died so many times.I am gonna get this out of the way right now.This game has hands down the BEST ENEMY AI i have ever seen in a video game.The enemies in this game are brutal.They take cover,they prefire(i am not kidding),they coordinate with each other,they cover a person that uses a medkit,they even FLANK you from behind the walls or above.Are you tired of stupid AI that is too basic,boring or run around like idiots?Try this game and find out.You think having a good gear or good aim will let you take a base easily?You are wrong.If you are not careful while walking in the base,you will get either sniped,flanked from a shotgun guy(=dead).You need carefully trace your steps.AtmosphereNow on to the atmosphere the game is less scary on the surface.The anomalies are easy to get used,the dogs are a bit scary if they are in a pack and the bandits are hard at the start but when you get better gear are a walk in the park.The milititary bases like i said above are the challenge.The underground gameplay though is terrifying.If you dont have night vision when you go in you are in for a challenge.The mutants living underground are creepy, and they can kill you pretty fast if you dont spot them quickly.I have seen 5 types of mutants and all were a challenge.Now as far as negatives go the Gunplay while it feels realistic is a bit clunky but thats because some weapons are bad or they are in bad condition.Dont think that aiming at the head will guarantee you a kill.You need to know about zeroing to take some shots.And the other negative are some framedrops at some locations even though i can runs far better games than this.And finally to pump you up a bit i will share with you one of the missions that led me to this review.I had to attack a bandit base so i waited out to get dark because enemies cant spot you that easily unless they spot you with the flashlights.I put a silencer on my TR301(Btw this game has many many weapons)and i killed everyone one by one.Then i entered the underground lab with only 50 bullets.Then i switched to my shotgun to deal with the creepy mutants in the dark.After i stole the the documents,a military hitsquad created an ambush on the surface to kill me,with helicopter lighting the exit so that i couldnt escape in the dark.The best part was the weather.A raging thunderstorm started while i was fighting the military out in the open.I was out of medkits,only had a few bandages left,my character was hungry and tired(out of stamina)and only 50 bullets to finish them.This was one of the coolest and most intense missions i have ever played in a video game.Props to the devs. Cheeki Breeki

number of helpful: 12 of 12 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23
												Assuming the role of the amnesiac stalker named the Marked One, you explore the various locations and areas in the Zone, an area in Chernobyl that was the site of an incident that created rifts in various locations called anomalies that have different effects when touched which ranging from a lightning, fire, to gravity-manipulation. [GAMEPLAY]An FPS-rpg which may be likened to games like Fallout New Vegas or Fallout 3, S.T.A.L.K.E.R Shadow of Chernobyl focuses more on the shooting mechanics such as giving the player an option to peek corners using a lean option, sprint for a certain distance which is determined by the stamina bar, and have access to different kinds of guns ranging from the common weapon categories such as pistols, shotguns, and rifles. The game features different quests given by different people of The Zone (will be discussed more later), it also contains RPG elements present in the form of quests, stats, weapon degradation, and inventory management. Stat manipulation acts more of a resistance mechanic and  can only be done through the acquisition of items called "artifacts" which can be randomly obtained in the different areas with anomalies or through containers,PROS: -Straightforward fps elements and simplified rpg elements that allows you to focus more on the former.-Gun variety and implementation of the weight system forces you to be more prudent in your weaponchoices.CONS: - Certain stats tend to be more important to others like bulletproof, radiation, and endurance. - The weapon accuracy of the game could be misleading at times. Even when you're using a rifle, shooting an enemy at a relatively close range will take you a couple of bullets. The game encourages the use of tap shooting instead of spraying.- Quests are repetitive. You're given the usual get this, get that, & kill this, kill that.- Gamebreaking quests that don't warn you of the consequences (To be discussed in the story portion)[SOUND]Music:While the game's music is not something to be praised, the sound effects created when you're in an underground research facility would really set up the mood, further enforcing the idea that you're not alone and that the mutated inhabitants of the Zone may just be in the next corner. [GRAPHICS]The game's age shows through its textures is lackluster in terms character design and structures and confusing layouts in terms of the level design. Enemy/NPC variety is limited to a mere 5-7 designs for humans which are usually designated by armor they're wearing while there are only about 5 mutant types in the game. Building's look relatively the same with the others in the area while level design tends to be confusing as the ingame map or quest tracker sometimes doesn't specify what floor or even accurately pin points the objective.[VOICE ACTING]Obviously not a strength of the game, I would have preferred if the developers of the game spoke in their native tongue and had subtitles for better immersion. Although finally hearing the phrase cheeki breeki made my day any time.Pros: Cheeki breekiCons: Pretty bad voice acting[STORYLINE]Playing as an amnesiac stalker named the Marked One who was originally thought to be dead, you are brought in by a local trader who asks you to do some work for him by running errands. You eventually get to meet the different factions in the game such as Freedom, Duty, and the Loner factions as you explore and unravel the mysteries of the Zone. PROS: Different possible endings depending on your actionsCONS: Game-breaking quest system that could possibly deter you from progressing through the game.[Bugs & Glitches]The game tends to have a lot of bugs as mentioned above but can be easily avoided by saving properly or using the quick load option. Other options such as fixes or patches online can be used to address this. Some I bugs I've experienced are  getting stuck in certain areas because of trying to reach certain places and factions becoming suddenly hostile to you because of a quest. Rating: 7/10Rating the game as more of an fps, I rated accordingly based on its genre/s, as an fps-rpg. Although the game shines more of as a fps, the rpg elements of the game only adds to its realism while being plagued with bad-level design, few npc and enemy types, and some game-breaking bugs which are easily-fixed.

number of helpful: 13 of 14 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R. SoC is a fantastic game, undoubtedly the most atmospheric game I've ever played, the level of immersion is absurd. You play as a Stalker, seeking wealth from the sale of artefacts found in the surrounding area of Chernobyl, however, the "Zone" is not a friendly place and danger throughout the game is constant.The gameplay is great, although a little rough at first sight, you need to play at a more measured pace, as I said, the Zone is dangerous, there are many enemies, from bandits and mercenaries, through military and enemy factions of stalkers, plus mutants and environment traps known as anomalies which can kill you instantly. The AI is very good and challenging, which uses efficient combat tactics. There are a wide variety of items, artefacts, weapons and ammunition necessary for progression. The game is graphically outdated but there are mods that greatly improve the look, the setting in the game is a strong point, combined with great sound effects which contribute a lot to the immersion factor, tension is inevitable in some places as enemies camps and underground laboratories.The plot is solid, despite being basically a shooter, there are RPG elements such as multiple endings which depend on your posture during the game, there are factions that you can be friendly, enemy or neutral, depending on your attitudes and choices. The game has a great replay value. One negative point are the side missions, they are shallow and poorly drawn up, become repetitive with time, which discouraged me to continue making them. The base game is known to have some bugs, by recommendations I played with the Complete 2009 mod, which fixes those bugs, improves graphics, AI, sounds, among other things.At the end, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is a unique game, I couldn't recommend it more. 9/10

content:
Posted: February 9
												As someone who loves role playing games, FPS games, and post apocalyptic games, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. SoC is a game you must play.I've read a lot of reviews about people's opinions on this game and almost everyone praises it but people disagree on if you should mod it and how you should mod it. Some people say play it without mods before you play it with mods. I think that's ridiculous. I'd say play this game with some sort of mod. No matter how you decide to play this game, ALWAYS play it on the hardest difficulty level. This is how the game is meant to be played no matter what. There are a few mods I can recommend. S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Complete 2009 is a decent mod that fixes bugs but it undeniably makes the game a little easier while keeping it almost the same as vanilla. Another mod I love is Autumn Aurora. You can look it up and find the most recent version, but this mod is my favorite. It adds an awesome ENB, better textures and a lot of new weapons. These are just a few things the mod actually does. Another couple popular mods are LURK and STALKERSOUP. I haven't played these but I've heard they're good.S.T.A.L.K.E.R. SoC is one the my favorite games of all time. It's very inexpensive and can grant you hundreds of hours of gameplay with all the mods out there.

content:
Posted: March 5
												An excellent open world survival FPS set in an alternative reality where a second nuclear disaster occurs at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant exclusion zone causing strange radioactive anomalies to appear and the wildlife to mutate in to horrific, twisted abominations.The gunfights are tense and require you to make every shot count because the enemies don't stand in the same spot or hide behind boxes like in some FPS' (*cough cough* COD), they will hunt you down and kill you. They're VERY good at hunting you down and killing you.The atmosphere is foreboding and oppressive and there's some genuinely frightening moments which you won't forget for a long time.This is a 10 year old game so the graphics, textures and animations look pretty goofy by today's standards but there are a lot of great mods which are easy to find and install which make the game look pretty stunning.Also be sure to create multiple saves and SAVE OFTEN, LIKE ALL THE FRIGGIN' TIME because this game will not hold your hand and it's very easy to screw yourself over if you don't have enough medical supplies or ammo and it's never fun to get 20 hours in to a game and realise you're going to have to load a save from 5 hours ago.For full immersion put on an Adidas track suit and squat in front of your computer holding a bottle of vodka.

												In a nutshell, this game is:10% Luck20% Skill15% Concentrated power of will5% Pleasure50% Painand a 100% reason why to buy this gameAs much as I enjoyed this game, your character kind of walks like a gangbanger from Compton, accuracy is annoying: unloading a whole magazine from a pistol or several shells into an enemy, you'll miss, even if they're in front of you. If you don't have bandages, you're screwed when you are hemorrhaging heavily.This game to me, is like the Russian Fallout (even though Metro is considered the Russian Fallout to some people), I enjoy the layout and the weaponry in this game.Weapons will degrade, ammo has weight, ammunition is scarce for some weapons.Weight is an issue as you will slow down a whole lot if you hold onto several items, forcing you to drop loads of items or drinking a lot of energy drinks to get from Point A to Point B.I would definitely recommend this game if you're looking for a challenge, this game has its horror moments, can be annoying at times but I would recommend it.

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												THE SHORT REVIEW:A cross between both Fallout and Metro, what's not to love about that? Shadow of Chernobyl is one of the best games of it's kind.THE LONG REVIEW:Shadow of Chernobyl has been in my Steam library (and backlog) for quite some time - haven't really had a chance to sit down and play the game, but after longing for something post-apocalyptic until Fallout 4, I'd thought that I would give this game a go. It's safe to say that Shadow of Chernobyl has become an instant favourite, and has immersed me within it's interesting world.The gameplay is fairly simple, if you've played an FPS then you should come to expect the usual, but what makes SoC interesting is it's environments and it's desolate world. Even though I love Fallout, there were some parts that didn't really capture the feeling of lost-hope or desolation, SoC on the other hand nails it completely. It's an interesting blend between world building and exploration that makes me want to know everything about what's going on, there's not really a "solid" story so your left to your own devices to investigate (at your own pace of course).SoC has a great way of getting you to become distracted by the strange things, and this curiosity makes the game great to play. The gameplay, however, is slightly hindered by it's save system. It can become a hassle because you have to make sure you have at least more than one saves (or your screwed). Depending on where or when you save can mean life or a quick death, which can be a gamble when it might or might not help you out in the end.Though combat is great, it can often unforgiving as there are moments where you might pelt someone with a load of bullets followed by a swift death. Again, depending on where you saved it might be the difference between having to redo a section or redo an entire quest. Luckily later on in the game you are given access to more formidable weapons making the combat much easier and quicker to complete.There were moments where I was invested into the gameplay, and then there were other moments where I felt like I needed a break from it. It also doesn't help that the game lacks a fast travel system, but it does add to the immersion (which is always a plus in my book). I'm sure with the help of mods there will be a way to fix some of these issues, and I'm most certain I'll be using them on a second playthrough.Shadow of Chernobyl is a first person shooter at heart, but it's a unique one none the less. There are so many survival elements and atmospheric set pieces that draw you into the game. It's not game of the year material, but it's certaintly one of the best survival games out there. Also as a compromise to Fallout's Galaxy News Radio I'd reccomend listening to Apocalypse Please by Muse (or any of their songs). I just happend to be listening to them while playing SoC and something just resonated. Enjoy!MADE FOR: Hardcore fans of the post apocalyptic genreNOT MADE FOR: Players that want an easy survival game (STALKER can be extremely unforgiving at times).STALKER: SHADOW OF CHERNOBYL 8.5/10

 S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl	This game is without a doubt a very good production however it is made on the X-Ray engine which in itself is not very good engine. Soundtrack is very good especially when we meet stalkers by the fire when they are playing on guitar. Russian dubbing gives incredible climate for the game. The game offers us two modes for single player and multiplayer. History tells us about a stalker who does forgot what had happened to him and he discovers that in your PDA has a note "Kill Strielok".In the game we will visit the large parts of the Zone. We will visit places such as Kordon, laboratories at Jantar filled with mutants and zombies, Pripyat a beautiful and also frightening place and also stunningly nuclear power plant in Chernobyl. The game offers us a wide arsenal of weapons starting with the usual guns ending with Gauss rifle. During an game player is forced to frequent management equipment because it is a not enough to carry everything. I recommend you also certain modifications called  Autumn Aurora 2.1  a really great mod completely changes the look of the game, adds new models of weapons, suits and improved animations. Also adds to the game emissions, new monsters, the ability to sleep and damage to suits and weapons but also their repair.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2016
												TL:DR;A game that was well ahead of its time, technically and thematically, and has an active modding community and positive reviews to this very day. Highly recommend checking this out, no matter what genre you're a fan of; there really is something here for everyone.FACTS: Released in 2007Inspired "[by] the popular science fiction novella Roadside Picnic by Boris and Arkady Strugatsky and the 1979 Andrei Tarkovsky film Stalker that was loosely based on it, as well as Stalker, the film's subsequent novelization by the original authors. -Wikipedia, sue meMETACRITIC: 82, 8.4 User ScoreHell, even IGN gave it an 8.2. (and they were whining about the technical limitations of an open-world FPS RPG made by indie developers in 200-and-flipping-7, and how the almost non-existent cutscenes were "badly compressed" despite the fact that Half Life proved you don't need cutscenes for a story to be told well.)________________________________________________________________________________OPINIONWhat the hell CANT you say about STALKER? Its critically renowned, a cult classic, STILL has an active modding community almost 9 years later, helped jumpstart the open-world RPG FPS genre mixture, has one of the most haunting and memorable atmospheres I've ever experienced in any form of media (and I'm a fan of horror) AND your crumb-filled, burnt-smelling toaster can run it now!Raving over a personal favorite of mine aside, whatever you don't initially like about this game, you'll come to like. What you won't come to like, you can mod out, or, in (a surprisingly large amount) some cases, in. Some things just can't be fixed however.Yes, it is open world. Yes, there are fences and loading screens between areas.Yes, it has an in-depth story, chock full of lore,personality, dark humor, and some pretty mature themes.Yes, most of it is behind walls of text that instead of reading, you'd rather be AH NUUUU CHEEKI BREEKI-ing the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of mutants.Yes, there are not a lot of guns.Yes, you can mod more in / mod them to feel better/more realistic.Yes, it can be buggy/glitchy/graphically dated.Yes, the fans have solved all three problems (mostly).Basically, pretty much any problem you have with the game can be solved by either sucking it up (which, in gaming, you shouldn't really be expected to), mod it in/out, or learn to love it.While it certainly has it cons, this is the one game I'm willing to overlook the glaring problems it has in favor of the spectacularly good parts of it.What S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl does wrong, it can be  made right, thanks to an active modding community. What is fundementally wrong with it can be easily brushed aside given the situation of the company and the state of video games as a whole in 2007. What cannot be looked over, modded out, or forgiven, is mostly fixed in the sequels.And what it does right? Oh, it does it so... sooooooo right.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												I played this game under the recommendation of the semi-famous youtuber "Life of Boris."The game follows the Marked One in his quest to find answers to who he is and what his purpose is. You begin in the "Zone," the area around where the Chernobyl Disaster in '86 happened. The disaster led to fantastic artifacts, with supernatural powers, and mutants. People came from far and wide to enter the zone and hunt down these priceless artifacts.You'll find plenty of highly-detailed areas to explore. Entering a place below ground level always gave me the heeby-jeebies.At first you may find this game completely unforgiving on normal mode, but if you stick with it, it gets easier. You WILL find better equipment and become a god. Try to get a scoped automatic, crouch down, and aim for the head. Any 5.56 weapon is good. You'll find plenty of 5.56 ammo on dead bodies. The aiming system is crappy but it is barely tolerable.The Zone has a certain Russian charm. I found it humorous that the bandit gopniks were wearing Adidas and shooting at me while screaming Cheeki Breeki. I found it also humorous that some friendlies were slav squatting in front of a campfire with a guitar, drinking vodka, while ignoring gunfire and mutants that are literally 50 yards away.This game was made with an outstanding amount of effort. I highly recommend it.P.S. This game took me 13 hours to beat. There were some technical issues due to the game's age but I was able to work around it after googling the answers.

Posted: September 14, 2013
Good game. It's got a few kinks in it but, you can get around them. It could have used a better engine imho but, it plays ok as it is. One thing for sure is, you can't just run and gun in this one. The choices you make, determines the outcome of the game and there's no Free-play at the end. In order to complete the game in it's entireity, (finding all the stashes and what-not) you'll have to replay it several times. It has many endings than just one, like most games. 7 endings, to be exact.It's worth the price and the graphics are ok for it's Era. It plays fine for me on W7. There are many mods to add for different types of gameplay as well but, I'd suggest playing it as is before trying out any mods. At least then, you'll know what the game was all about and how it was meant to be.Update: If you really want this game and the others as well, do not purchase them here UNLESS, they're on a super sale or, something. Steam is greedy with games of choice like these so, buy them with a bundle or, where you can get them for a lesser price. All of them are great games but, there's no more updates and or, the like for them anymore.One of the best fps games ever.

												An open world FPS game with survival horror and RPG elements. The story takes place in the "Zone" the area around the nuclear power plant of Chernobyl, where a second disaster has taken place. If you inted to play it you should download the Complete Mod which fixes the game's problems and improves the graphics, A.I. and more.90%

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												The Stalker series is easily some of the most fun I've had playing a video game in recent memory, surpassing even AAA titles. This is the first, Shadow of Chernobyl, and it's a very enjoyable experience.Now that that's out of the way, I'll move on to the important stuff.When you fire up a STALKER game for the first time, one of two things will happen; either it will load without incident, or the game will crash. It's a fact of life; the sun shines, it's currenty 8:00 AM as I write this, and STALKER games like to crash for no particular reason. Disabling the Steam overlay in-game and fiddling with the graphics options, or disabling whatever mods you may have active seems to fix most problems, but sometimes you'll get a bug that, no matter what you do, will not go away. In that case, it's time to hit the Internet and hope that someone has a fix, which, more often than not, they do. When you do get the game to work, start it on a higher difficulty than normal. Sounds stupid, but there's a reason for that. STALKER does a lot of weird things to the guns on lower difficulties, including making a certain amount of shots (both your's and the enemy's) fade completely out of existence before hitting the target. If you're wondering why your gun isn't hitting anything even thought you've got the crosshairs on your scope lined up right on the target's head, that's why. Also, everything on the low difficulties is a bullet sponge. You are too, but only until the end, where the enemies kill you by so much as staring in your general direction. You still die fast on the higher difficulties, but now the enemies will, too. Just remember to save often to prevent crashes from erasing the last hour of progress.If you've gathered one things from that last paragraph, it's probably that the game is pretty hard. It is, although it's also fair. You die after a few hits, but so do most enemies that aren't armored or bigger than you. In addition, every human enemy can be instantly killed by shooting them in the head with any weapon in the game (although you will need armor piercing ammo to do the same for the guys in the late-game). If you can deal with the iron sights and semi-automatic fire rate on your assault rifle, you can get through the game without much issue, although it's still a good idea to invest in better guns and optics; the iron sights on all guns tend to be a little bit hard to find. By that, I mean that the sights are off, and the bullets like to go everywhere. On the starting Makarov handgun, for example, the sights resemble a brick set between two other, differently colored bricks (although, to be fair, this is how Makarov sights look in real life). The bullets also go a little higher than you would expect. The rifles have the same problems, but they can be fixed by grabbing a scope and slapping the two together. And hey, you can take the scope off when it's time to upgrade your equipment, so you're not stuck buying another one!Speaking of equipment, there's weapon degradation in STALKER. The good news is that, unlike the other games, you can sell your stuff no matter how broken it is. The bad news is that there's no way to fix the stuff you like. So, if you found that Desert Eagle chambered for 9x39 rounds, you might want to be careful how you use it, because that gun absolutely wrecks everything and there's only one in the entire game. Oh yes, there's also load times. They're not that bad, but there's a lot of them. Whenever you go into a new area, it takes a few seconds to load, so get used to that.The good news is, that's pretty much the extent of the bad. Now, let's talk about the good.STALKER has managed to blend elements of RPG games and FPS games in a good way. It's still a FPS game, mind you, and it doesn't have experience points or any way of leveling up, but it does have a healthy amount of inventory management. During my playthrough of this game, I spent more time messing about with my guns and ammo than I did in Resident Evil 4. Be warned that bringing up your inventory does not pause the game; you can still move while rearranging things, and enemies can still attack you. If you want to pause, hit the ESC key.The Zone is an excellent setting full of whimsy and terror. I spent just as much time frolicking over hills while drinking enough vodka to give a troubled Soviet general alcohol poisoning as I did crawling through decrepit buildings with my flashlight on, hoping a Bloodsucker wasn't waiting around the next corner, ready to tear my throat out. It really captures what it feels like living in modern-day Russia, except Russia in real life has more mutants than in STALKER.The guns are a bit finicky, but the shooting feels fun and rewarding. The recoil is harsher than in most games, which is all the more reason why you should use semi auto.Disregarding the crashes, the game runs pretty well. I only saw it start to sputter in a few cases, and it actually didn't crash on me that much. I believe I had an issue where it crashed whenever I tried to start a new game, and after that, it crashed two or three more times, but both of those were fixed by just firing the game up again. It wasn't as bad as New Vegas, that's for sure. So, should you buy STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl? That depends. If you're a fan of open-world games like New Vegas, then you will enjoy this game. I highly recommend it.

S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl - old but radioactive!This piece of art is about the nuclear accident in Chernobyl (1986). We write the year 2012 and You have to go into the destroyed environment which is called "the zone" to complete your last task - find and kill Strelok. "The zone" is dangerous - radioactivity, mutants, mercenary and the army will make your life hard.Stalker is (in my opinion) a mixture of (singleplayer) RPG and (Horror-)Ego-Shooter. You run through destroyed areas, kill bandits, search for ammo or food and find information.The RPG share consists of the possibilty to acquire reputation in the various fractions (freedom, guardians and so on), to do different tasks and receive different equippable weapons, ammo and armor types.positive arguments incoming!++ you can drink vodka++ open world!!!!111++ the KI isn't that stupid++ lively atmosphere++ 7 different endings (5 bad, 2 good)+ no overpowered weapons+ you sh.it your pants in the dark labors...+ the sounds are disturbing and realistic+ the graphics are still handsome (you can patch that)+ nice story (like every "older" game)+ the sidequests...are ok...still the same (find that/kill that)+ you will see "the red forest", Pripyat, and the NPS (nuclear power station) of Chernobyl...reactor 4the negative aspects are not many, but see:- no fast traveling :(- (no skill or perk system)- you can't repair your equipment- sometimes a bit boring- hard to understand @ the first time-/+ no "BIG" actionIn my opinion it is one of the best post-apocalyptical game and perhaps even Metro 2033! The open world makes it much more fantastic (the biggest minus of Metro2033). The accident really happened not to this extent but it happened! The dark basements and labors will plss yourself and this, this is what I want in a Horror-Survival game. The fear that an invisible mutant will eat my face or to go deeper into the zone...Who comes with me to Chernobyl?9/10 vodka bottles--> for those who want improved graphics: http://www.moddb.com/mods/autumn-aurora-compilation-mod

												An open world FPS game with survival horror and RPG elements. The story takes place in the "Zone" the area around the nuclear power plant of Chernobyl, where a second disaster has taken place. The place is filled with mutants and diferrent factions  which fight for control of the Zone. The atmosphere of the game is great which helps a lot with the immersion. It's not really scary but it can make you feel uneasy and anxious sometimes. The shooting mechanism is pretty good as is the trading one. You can buy items with money or trade stuff you don't need for them. The graphics are good enough for a game of 2007, but the game is suffering from a lot of bugs. If you inted to play it you should download the Complete Mod which fixes the game's problems and improves the graphics, A.I. and more.90%

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												Well now, Stalker, Shadow of Chernobyl. I Tried it twice, in the past, couldn't get past the first bloodsucker, pooped my pants. So after a couple of years, with a pair of grown up balls (:d) I gave it another go, and, boy, am I glad I did. I was pulled right away into the Zone and I just couldn't force myself out of it. I played on stalker difficulty with complete mode 2009, i don't do hard mode on first play troughs. Even so, it was quite challenging at the end, as I entered Chernobyl complete unprepared, with zero med kits in the bag and all the wrong artifacts. That was not a walk in the park. All in all, it took me almost 40 hours with many side quests, and now I think of those 40 hours as some of the best in my 12-13 years of gaming history. The atmosphere is  unique, running trough the post apocaliptic abandoned and creepy Pripiat, followed by a dozen mutated dogs and some other ugly as♥♥♥♥♥♥monsters while shot by snipers and trapped by anomalies is quite strangely awesome.  I can't recommend this game enough. Get it if you can,  should be affordable by now, I payed 4 dollars for the steam code. Use complete mode 2009 for improved graphics and much more, and enjoy! 10 out of 10 from me.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl was the very first game of the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series I played. The game takes place in an alternate reality, with the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone being the setting. The Chernobyl Exclusion Zone is a 30 square Kilometer area surrounding the Cernobyl Nuclear Power Plant which suffered a catastrophic explosion and subsequent meltdown in the 1980's. This "Zone" in the game is home to mutant creatures such as Dogs, Boars, Birds, and Humanoid Creatures, as well as S.T.A.L.K.E.R's who are treasure and artifact hunters, guides, and mercenaries paid to work in and around the Zone. The game takes place over 20 years after the initial disaster, when a second disaster occurs creating pockets of radioactivity and producing anomalies. This is where the main character comes in. You play in First Person as an amnesiac S.T.A.L.K.E.R, nicknamed The Marked One. You are rescued by one of the locals and in exchange you perform tasks and go on missions, while trying to figure out who you are and why you lost your memory. As far as First Person Shooters go, S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is one of the more fun ones; However, there are a few bugs. Enemy soldiers respawn way to quickly in some areas, NPC's even Quest NPC's are mortal and will stay dead if killed, making some NPC's difficult to contact or keep alive for long, on the harder difficulty settings. The Game AI is very adaptable, making the NPC's react differently depending on the tactics you choose to use. The environment is also errie, and when played at night, in the dark with headphones really makes you feel immersed in the game. The story is interesting, though told a piece at a time through missions and meeting new contacts. I recommend playing S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky first since it is technically a prequel to Shadow of Chernobyl, though S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl stands strong on it's own even for a 7-year-old game  and is worth the price to play.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												To this day this game remains the standard I compare adventure and survival games to, especially in the open-world non-linear category. Other reviews will use the term "ahead of its time" and in many ways they are right, but the term I wish to emphasize is "Masterpiece".I don't know how I came across this game, I think my bestie told me to check it out sometime back in 2006/7; after finally acquiring it, putting a few hours in, I realized that I have been feeling something I hadn't felt since my Freshman year roommate presented me with Fallout 2 back in 2000. (Yes I've played Bethesda's Fallout games, yes they are enjoyable, well-made and recommended, but the bottom line is that I compare FO3/FO4 to Stalker, and Stalker did it better, end of argument).I have played it a total of 7 times since 2007, meticulously finishing all the unique side quests and story-lines, and on a number of occasions, playing one of the overhaul project mods that add tons of content and fix the vanilla issues I remember suffering through playing back in 2007. Yes, I suffered from the stupid decision to release the game before it was completed, but it is so good I went ahead and played it any ways! There were many frustration moments back then, and I learned valuable lessons about Hard Saves and questing management, so if you haven't played the game, I envy you, because you will get to enjoy this Masterpiece after it has ages splendidly.I'll start with the Cons:-You shouldn't play the Vanilla, not when excellent overhaul mod projects exist. The game has been patched by the original development team but there are still some bugs that can be really annoying.-This game will test your limits, both in patience and resilience, mirroring in a way the plight of the protagonist. There will be moments when you jump scared, and others when you jump screaming in rage.-This is an FPS game, so shooting is mostly how you solve your problems. The trick to thinking outside the box is how to circumvent your problem so you won't have to shoot in the first place (or shoot a lot less)! Don't expect much from the dialogue resolution options nor expect high levels of stealth options in missions, but sneaking around can both be useful and rewarding!Pros:-Immersive, beautiful and haunting. It's not a huge world, which allows you to truly bond with each location as many locations will be revisited so many times as you quest and adventure on.-Strong story-line, lore and voice casting. Just the right amount of Sci-Fi-Realism fusion.-A user-friendly interface and control system that doesn't concern itself with console 'peasants' (Sorry Bethesda, but your UI needs serious remodeling, it's the main reason I stopped playing your games)-Great gun action, great thriller moments, heart-pounding narrow-escapes. Gun handling feels authentic, combat is exhilarating.-The game ages like fine wine, with texture mods and 1080p support you won't believe this is an 8 years old game coming from the Ukraine.I'm tired, and hungry, go play the game if you haven't, you'd be a fool not to!

												The vivid imagery and the sheer feeling of a cold, harsh landscape is something this game accurately displays and in great detail. The characters, the setting, the entire story has a very humble, yet intense feel to how you plan your adventure from one zone to the next. The conflict of deciding whether to remain hidden to save yourself or confront the various creatures in order to obtain a much needed quest item is a tough situation, and one I find coming across a lot. It becomes very clear that radiation isn't the only danger here.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												That I've taken so many years to get round to playing S.T.A.L.K.E.R is criminal. It's awesome. Like the kind of game no one should miss out on awesome. I picked it up for a fiver along with Call of Pripyat and Clear Sky. If you're reading this review considering buying the game and you like open world RPG games/shooters/Russians - just go do it. With the 2009 complete mod you're able to enable the likes of HDR lighting etc as well, so the game looks pretty great for coming out almost 10 years ago.Combat is tense and exciting and the weapon and armour varieties are cool. Atmosphere is top notch, I love the sound design, like if it's raining and you hide in a bush the rain is muffled falling on the leaves around you. The game is full of nice little details.Story is ok, but some of the translation into English is a bit rough and lacking in proper grammar :P. Still, it doesn't diminish the game at all, it actually makes it more believable that you're near Chernobyl.Definite 10/10

												A dark lab, once inhabited by scientists, it is now the breeding nest for their creations, a city once big and prosperous is now lying silent, only the usual crows can be heard arguing over a dead body of an unfortunate soldier, who's chopper got downed by the Monolith. Nobody in these northern parts, excepting the monolith, mutants and the poor stalker who got too greedy and went into the Red Forest: zombies, no soul, no mind, only instincts and hatred towards everything which lives, not very different from them are the monolith, only that they ''allied themselves'' and praise the ''allmighty monolith'', but, to the south, there is a different life, people talk, laugh, cry, cheer, all of them are in a different factions which tries to reach the north first, so big is the desire, that they got themselves into a so-calles faction war which lasts for an year now, but everybody knows that just 5 people managed to get to the center, Fang- a technician, also a mule of sorts, Ghost- a master of stealth, Doctor- can heal virtually anyone and anything, Guide- knows a path towards anything and last but not least, Strelok- the mastermind behind it all, but he has now dissapeared, and he doesn't know that a misterious stalker is on his tail, apparently he got brainwashed, doesn't remember anything, what happened, who is he? You will have to find out, this game well deserves a 10/10 rating from me.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2012
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R Shadow of Chernobyl is a game that should come with a warning label of sorts. It is a game that has that rough about to explode feeling that some of the more unpolished games tend to give off. The animation is a little off, the difficulty tends to jump all over the place, the text is often complete gibberish thanks to a shoddy Russian to English translation and the game is generally very unoptimized. Yet it's a fun game. Despite all it's flaws Shadow of Chernobyl manages to hit some of the right keys that makes it a great gaming experience.Shadow of Chernobyl is an open-ended first person shooter taking place in and around the highly radioactive Chernobyl area. Now, this isn't the real world birth defect causing radiation, it's the more fun and cherry cartoon radiation that in this world causes mutated monster animals and a variety of spatial anomalies.As you travel the world of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. you will encounter various factions fighting it out in the "zone" as they call it, all with hilariously translated dialog. You do missions, find secrets and fight the wilderness and the people in at as you make your way towards ground zero of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster to discover the truths about what has happened here.Shadow of Chernobyl is a game that should receive a mediocre review anywhere based on it's rather massive technical problems but it somehow manages to overcome it's difficulties thanks to some solid basic gameplay and a strong modding community. A real underdog hit.

												Shadow of Chernobyl is a first-person shooter survival horror game . This game is highly rated and untill you sink some hours into it you won't understand why , the accuracy in the guns is the biggest draw back to playing it , which is a pretty big mechanic in a game like this. It has a non linear story with rpg elemets which allows you to roam the map (zone) and take part in random events. It also has a trade system within the game allowing you to upgrade gear etc .I played the first half of this game without any mods and really struggled to find the energy to carry on playing due to bugs and the accuracy of the guns which is very frustrating.The second half of the game i used the "Complete Stalker 2009" mod and it made the game 100X better. I enjoyed playing this game and may eventualy return to experience the various endings .

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												I'm late to the show. I first tried STALKER when it came out half a gaming century ago, but my rig sucked. I was pleased to see, that it runs like a charm on my relatively modern machine.First of all: The game is old. Do not expect up to date visuals, do not expect to find a modern UI. Expect to move your hand a lot over the keyboard, because those hotkeys are scattered like they were in the day. Expect to push your mouse over buttons in menus.You should also refrain from expecting a fast paced shooter. STALKER will kick your♥♥♥♥♥ Do not expect to land a head shot with a pistol over long distances. STALKER features some pseudo realistic mechanics, which are not 1:1 real physics but give you a rough feeling about what it means to fire an old worn out gun during a rainy day at a moving target.When I first launched the game and started moving around, I got a little dizzy, because the head bobbing is a little more than I can digest. It's an old but famous game, so naturally I looked for mods. The first hit brought me to a mod package, that tries to fix some bugs and combat annoyances, while trying to retain as much of the vanilla state as possible. Have a look at the "Zone Reclamation Project".The difficulty is good. I play on "Veteran", the second hardest of four settings. I expected to die a lot, being punished for being careless and exactly that happens. One dog, one soldier, one mutant no problem, but as soon as I rush in and overlook one of them, the surround me and I'm dead.I like how this game can do without pseudo RPG crap. While there is an inventory system and everything has multiple stats, there is no EXP, no skill tree and no character stat farming. Jobs (quests, missions) give you money and equipment and allow you to progress in the story.Let's see if this turns out to be more than run around and shoot bad guys. The scenario is promising.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												This is hands down, the best single player game I have played. The atmosphere is fantastic and unlike any other game out there. it was in development for years and even though they didn't manage to include everything they wanted, what they did is still incredible. this is no Console shooter or port, if you want a simple run and gun don't buy it and play for 20 minutes and complain when unlike Crysis you can't kill everything in 10 seconds with your hi tech gun and invincible **** suit.First of all, don't play it without downloading the Complete mod for free first. This updates the textures, sounds, AI, fixes a load of bugs and errors and makes the game what it wanted to be. It doesn't change anything, just cleans it all up.This game isn't like other FPS because it is actually hard. You don't start off with an amazing gun and squad and intel, you have a coat and a pistol and aside from that you are on your own. The Zone is an easy place to die even without having a host of powerful mutants and heavily armed humans roaming around. This game doesn't hold your hand like Western shooters do, or load you up with amazing gear under the guise of being some Spec Ops soldier. The atmosphere is incredible, part's of it are creepy as hell and scary and not like the Doom3 teen equivalent of having a monster jump out when you press the door button or a loud bang etc. It is hard to get into because it is so unforgiving, and the first few maps and missions you are constantly trying to find a decent weapon that doesnt force you to retreat when outnumbered etc. If you want a linear shooter like HL2 or CoD with no freeplay, dialogue or exploration and lots of cutscenes then look elsewhere. There are plenty of games liek that around. if you want a slow hard atmospheric adventure then give it a try, turn out all the lights and play it till the sun comes up; call in sick and keep on playing.10/10

content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R.:SoC is the Dark Souls of the FPS genre. Some will love it, some will hate it. I keep deleting what I'm saying, so I'll just bullet point pros and cons.PROS:-Brilliant setting: Chernobyl has been a place I have wanted to visit for a long time. It is essentially a place on earth that has been frozen in time, and the ability to explore it can be extremely immersive at times. Pripyat in particular offers amazing urban combat, allowing you to snipe from windows in high apartment buildings or taking the fight to the irradiated alleyways of the city.-White-knuckle tension: SoC has the ability to literally keep you on the edge of your seat at times, especially underground areas where light is dim and monsters lurk in the shadows. You will have to memorize enemy movements and behavior to get through certain areas in one piece. Blowouts/emissions will keep you on your toes as well, which are massive releases of radiation that will require you to make your way to shelter as quickly as you can, or die. -Active modding community: The devs of this game made sure to make the game files accessible from a modding perspective. I'm currently playing through using a mod called "Autumn Aurora" which improves almost all aspects of the game, and ENB, to make the shadows darker and lighting more contrasted. Many other mods exist that enhance the difficulty, add areas, and create entirely new experiences.-Beautiful visuals: First off, I agree that the game has not aged in the best way, but some aspects of the visuals still look better that some AAA games today, especially the lighting system. Visual mods go a long way in improving the textures, flora and fauna as well. The setting, while bleak and rainy most of the time, will occasionally show off on a sunny day, creating beauty in a dangerous world where death lurks around every corner.-Fantastic gunplay: SoC is unforgiving at times, but in the majority of cases, it will be due to your own error. To counter this, the game offers great shooting mechanics, including ricochets, bullet trajectory, and penetration. A wide (but not too wide) selection of weaponry allows each gun to have a specific feel and personality, which makes choosing which to pick up and which to drop very important.-Challenge and difficulty: PLAY ON MASTER. I cannot stress this enough. Difficulty and overcoming it is what makes the STALKER series so great. It makes victory that much more rewarding. Play smart and carefully, and Master difficulty is beatable on a first playthrough.-Sound: The sound design in SoC is unique and fits the setting like a glove. The beeps of your PDA, the wind rustling in the trees, your geiger counter warning you of nearby radiation, and enemies spewing insults to you in Russian during firefights all add to a wonderful (and terrifying) sense of immersion. CONSStory: The STALKER franchise does not rely on it's narrative to tell the story, which to some, may seem like a terrible mistake. It depends on what you look for in games. I believe that the setting tells it's own story, but you may disagree. I love a good story, but in SoC's case I believe that certain gameplay elements make up for the weak storyline. I should also mention that my game is in Russian, which makes comprehension quite difficult for myself, a native English speaker. Animations: Reload and NPC animations can be a bit strange looking at times. It's entirely possible that the game was created without motion capture due to a lack of resources, which can take you out of the experience at some points. Several mods, however, attempt to improve these faults. A very promising mod called "Gunslinger" is being released soon for STALKER: Call of Pripyat, which vastly improves all animations. Worth taking a look.Linearity: While the game does offer quite a large area in total to explore, it can sometimes feel linear. Radiation pockets and anomalies keep you mostly on the roads or in towns, cutting quite a bit of forest out from exploring. However, the forests in the real Chernobyl are some of the most irradiated in the world, so it does make sense. Take that as you will.That's all I can really think of. If you see this game on sale, make sure to grab it while it's cheap. It truly is a wonderful experience overall.9.5/10CHEEKI BREEKI IV DAMKE♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥

												Whew. Learned enough Russian to know "sucka" must not be a good name to be called and "grenatu" means grenade.+Tense gameplay+Good graphics+Realistic feel to weapons+Story is attaching. For me, at least.+Damn vortexes.-Game has a very slow start. Takes a while before you can sprint nonstop to cut the crap of walking a lot, and get a weapon that shoots in a relatively straight line. Get the Vintar Special Sniper Rifle, by the way. You get used to the bullet drop.-There are some weird bugs around quicksaving and NPC hostility that can get under your skin if they happen in certain conditions that, guess what, happened to me. *sigh* I didn't even want that revolver anyways.=It's not a horror game, though it can get creepy at times. And there's that one time you'll get scared the sh...eet of silk out of you. Just hide behind a wall and shoot it around the corner.=Most non-essential NPCs speak Russian, and only Russian. That means, like me, you'll have to get used to hearing "sucka," "grenatu" and that set of words they say when they refuse to talk to you while you don't lower your weapon.=The game's not really attached to decision-making. Don't expect Fallout-ish dialogue moments. Shoot everything that shoots first on sight.8.5/10 A very nice experience.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												In this game you roam around a bleak landscape and dying horribly either to mutants, bullets, or radiation. And you will die because this game is pretty brutal in its difficulty. It also is filled with NPC's who hate the player character and tell you to go away and will likely shoot at you if you take too long.It's also pretty good. It's post-apocalypse and almost a survival horror game where you have to worry constantly about lurking threats that will most certainly kill you if you are not careful. Also it has a pretty decent story, though one you can easily ignore due to the massive amounts of side-quests there are.In short... it's kinda like a Russian Fallout, though set in Ukraine. It's quite similar to Metro 2033 in its atmosphere, though this game is an FPSRPG rather than just a straight shooter like that game is. This is the first in a series of three games (sadly there won't likely be anymore since the devs are dead), so if this series interests you at all, then this would be the likely starting point.Have fun! :D

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2
												(Don't be fooled by the low playtime on my profile. I've been playing this through Steam on Wine, so I've had to do a lot of it in offline mode.)If I told anyone that a game made by Ukrainian indie devs on a completely custom engine was one of the best games I've ever played, they'd look at me funny.Anyone who has played S.T.A.L.K.E.R. would immediately agree.The X-ray engine, while quirky and strange at times, has (reportedly) the most true-to-life shooting model ever. Not that this is any solace when you try to mag dump on a mutant and die to it's melee attacks. The engine also does an amazing job with the general atmosphere of the game. It feels spooky and overbearing, like a good horror game should.When I say this game is scary, I genuinely mean it. Everyone has been in one of those creepy basements with peeling paint, no light, and an awful dusty smell. Now you get to explore those basements with ACTUAL MONSTERS. It does an amazing job of making you panic when you hear heavy breathing.  The mutants, unlike other games which the enemies stop being a threat eventually, remain a continual threat even to the end of the game.The story is great, while a bit ham-fisted, is a great medium for the overall experience.The best news: The game works perfectly in Wine, so Linux/Mac users need not miss out on this fantastic game.
