content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Every now and then a game which is one-of-a-kind and offers a completely unforgettable experience is made. This is one of those games. If you haven't tried S.T.A.L.K.E.R. before then now is the time. This FPS/RPG provides a realistic experience through proper weapon and damage mechanics and a special "A-Life" AI engine which allows The Zone to continue living and changing even when the player isn't there. This game does not provide an easy start for newcomers, dropping you into the harsh and desolate Zone with nothing but a jacket and a pistol. But it will reward players who continue onward using common sense and quick judgement to overcome the myriad of obstacles on their journey to the Center of The Zone. If you haven't tried this game, try it. But don't try for 5 minutes and then give up because it's "too hard". Give it a couple of hours and in those hours think to yourself "If I was actually in The Zone, what would I do?"Good hunting S.T.A.L.K.E.R. See you in The Zone.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												This game has had a pretty notorious reputation not long after it was announced in the early 2000's. It underwent numerous different designs, names, and builds before finally getting released in late 2007. Even then, some felt that the game was still a rushed beta, and honestly it was. It wasn't until several patches that the game was decently stable. However to many people, the game's now-trademark atmosphere, brutal gameplay and unforgiving gameplay environment were enough to leave the game permanently ingrained in gamer's minds across the globe.Flash forward to 2013, and this game still has a devoted modding community who are regularly working on and releasing ambitious new total conversions, weapon packs, gameplay tweaks and even restorations of previously-cut content. This game must be experienced first-hand. Even the base 2007 game is still good today, though the game truly shines once one ventures out and starts downloading various mods that make the game several orders of magnitude better. This reviewer here prefers 'Oblivion Lost 2.2', which is based on a previous version of the game -- it restores many gameplay concepts and features that were left out for reasons unknown. It adds in more weapons, more suits, creatures, improved graphics, smoother performance, vehicles, and even free-play. It also adds in complete A-Life, which is unlocked after a player beats the game with the best ending, where every STALKER in the Zone begins to operately totally freely, which can open up many unique scenarios which no two players will experience the same. The story is fairly gripping, though players expecting constant cutscenes and characters who never shut up will be disappointed. The story is told primarily through notes left in PDA's and some interactions with other humans face-to-face, though the few cutscenes there are do a wonderful job of contributing to the haunting atmosphere the game promotes. The gameplay is tough and unforgiving -- this game isn't for the noobs out there. You won't be charging at enemies doing 1080-degree backflips while going for no-scopes here. You have to pick your shots and battles carefully. Sometimes it's better to flee than fight, or use stealth to completely dodge enemies (or ambush them to take their loot!) STALKER in essence is an FPSRPG. You've got the traditional first-person shooter gameplay, combined with an inventory system, a stats system for both weapons and equipment, the latter of which directly affects the player's endurance and performance, quests, NPC's to interact with, and a fully dynamic open world that is constantly alive. The harsh environment, dubbed "The Zone", is as much a challenge as the humans and mutants you must deal with on a daily basis. Due to the events which took place prior to the game, the Zone has changed drastically, and there are mutant creatures and "anomalies" scattered everywhere. Careless players will go on raids without enough equipment, or foolishly walk through dark areas without watching their step, only to find themselves getting insta-gibbed by an anomaly. The A.I. is nothing to snicker at either, and they get even tougher if you play with most mods. Don't be surprised to be in a firefight with someone, only to lose track of them and then have them sneak up behind you and offload half a magazine into the back of your skull. Shadow of Chernobyl also boasts a pretty barebones multiplayer component, but in all honesty, this pales in comparison to the single-player experience, which is a shame. It can be fun for a little while, but several gameplay decisions quickly make it evident that it's easy to become overpowered against other players, making the experience very un-STALKER like. All in all, this game is worth the asking price, even years later. Buy this damned game, it's worth it.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												The start of the bleak ex-bloc survival shooter. STALKER SoC is an example of a systems-heavy open world FPS, that does an amazing job of demonstrating the broader potential within the genre. The mix of exploration, survival, hostile environment, and warring factions, makes for a much more compelling setting than any standard military or tactical shooter. The story of SoC is particularly strong, despite leaning on an amnesiac opening, and with multiple endings, you'll at least want to keep a few save files on hand. Travel and exploration are both dangerous and rewarding. Managing your inventory is a challenge, requiring mastery in itself. If you go into Stalker expecting to be an RPG-style pack mule, you'll be disappointed. For all that it does so well, and the ways in which it innovates, I don't feel that the game as released is truly "complete". While I'd recommend playing it in vanilla, for your first run through (and you'll probably want a second), I can't recommend "Oblivion Lost" too highly, when it comes to revisiting the game. Previously empty areas of the map are filled, new creatures introduced, and others taken to a superior state. If you ever wondered how the "Psuedodog" got its name, you'll figure that out pretty quick, in a playthrough of Oblivion Lost. If you're a fan of the FPS genre, this is a must for you to experience. The Zone is not for the feint of heart, but it is a pivotal stop for FPS fans.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												Think Metro 2033 but more sandboxy and with more realistic gameplay.Or Operation Flashpoint but you are the Russians and it's fun. All that said, the first time I bought Stalker and loaded it up I only lasted a hour before it bailed out on me and crashed repeatedly everytime I tried playing it. A game that I can't play 0/10.About three years later I made a second attempt, this time with a new computer. I began running around waving a pistol around in a environment that looked like it was built by a map editor on a Sunday afternoon. It could have had a better start, but better starts nothing when I realized how much I enjoyed it while engaged in street-level fighting armed with a laser rifle while backed by some cheap knockoffs of the Brotherhoods of Steel from Fallout 3. All this in day long gaming sessions that would generally be considered 'unhealthy' by those who have successful social lives. But it's a testament for how addicitng and honest-to-god engaging this game was for me with its sense of realism, acute open-worldiness, and how I feel like I am treated like someone with brains if I want to win rather than the tiptoe-through-the-garden-markers-on-every-interactable that so many other games *cough Assassin's Creed cough* do. I really don't know why I'm constantly comparing Stalker to other games, but let it be said that Stalker did come out in 2003, before all of them, so let's put a big medal for originality then eh?8.5/10

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												Nostalgia prevents me from delcaring this my top game over HL2, but S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is brilliant. It's certainly highly flawed in some aspects (nothing that a few of the many avaliable mods can't fix), it manages to capture the eerie beauty and tantalizing allure of the mysterious and dangerous. Fusing horror, immersion, realism, gunplay, and atmosphere without any subtracting from another and without, sacrificing any of the 'fun' factor, as many overly-ambitious games do. It creates an expansive, ominous world, (rivaling that of Fallout) riddled with sprawling underground bunkers and tunnels and military and commercial complexes full of loot and danger. The gunplay is intense and real-feeling, as you have as much HP as most humans and take equal damage from weapons, leaving you only with the advantage of wits and strategy when going up against a well-equipped opponent, and the mutants are terrifying and strangely numerous. Creeping nervously through a dark subterranean laboratory and peeking around a corner to glimpse some strange, grotesque creature you've never seen before is never loses it's thrill, and is a perplexingly common occcurence, even after playing the game for some time. The game's faults (dismal ambient sounds, bugs, etc.) are more than tolerable given the game's many and unique strengths. All in all, fantastic game. 9.1/10

If you are just starting out on this game, play it through in vanilla on first playthrough (just a warning it.. can be sometimes buggy and unpredictable in vanilla, from my experience anyway) and once you've completed the game, I would recommend downloading a mod. It can be any mod of your choice (obviously) but I would highly recommend something like AMK or Oblivion Lost, they're both fairly simplistic, both add new features but nothing too big. They also add things like new weapons, armour and what not, don't worry, it doesn't dumb the game down like that awful excuse for a mod Stalker Complete, it's still a challenge, so never fear! As for StalkerSoup, it is difficult I would only recommend this to experienced STALKER players (!seriously!) but you can have a go if you want. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												Where do I start with this game? I've played through it twice and am currently on my third play through after beating the trilogy a few years ago. I downloaded the STALKER Complete 2009 mod which I hoped would refresh the game without introducing stupid gameplay imbalances. I was right. It's still one of the greatest and most demanding open-world first person role playing games out there. And I think I would be justified in saying that it on its own rivals the AAA competitors like Fallout 3 or New Vegas. It's just that good.It plays really nicely, and because it's such an old game it runs smoothly with high anti-aliasing and high frame rates. As a core game you are sort of thrown into the combat with little preparation, but it doesn't take an experienced shooter-player to realize that you need to duck and cover. Leaning is super important, and enemies like to shoot when you move forcing you to play patiently and not go commando. That being said, once you get the formula down, you just sit and pop enemies when they poke their heads out. Pretty standard. The real challenge is fighting monsters which will scare the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you and really put your twitch-shooter skills to the test. Interacting with friendlies and setting out on quests is easy enough, but oftentimes the quests will end in ways you don't expect due to the uncertain nature of everything occurring in the game-world. You plan an ambush with some buddies and only you made it out? That's your fault but you gotta move on.The Complete 2009 mod really polishes off the game nicely. Textures are still pretty sharp, and the world is brimming with anomalies and enemies. You really notice the subtle touches like rain pouring outside and forcing friendlies to huddle inside next to barrel stoves. The sound is good but definitely dated. I really like having to use directional sound to orient myself and in a game like this that feature really stands out. The day-night cycles are intense and I found myself sleeping through the nights so as to have a daylight advantage in combat.The story is super intriguing and really enhanced by the dark and radioactive atmosphere. Everything could be dangerous and you gotta be on your game if you want to make it out alive. What's awesome is that you can play this game multiple times and get fairly different experiences in terms of the narrative and your late-game character's attributes. Some people go full ecologist and collect anomalies to enhance their character. Some seek the best guns ever. Some have the best armor. It's all pretty standard for the genre, but it is executed well and provides a player with a large range of choices to make throughout the story.Addendum: So I beat it after reloading a quick save every 15 minutes because holy ♥♥♥♥ the monolith stalkers really throw everything in the game at you including gunships, mutants, armor piercing ammunition, and their sheer numbers (I killed maybe 40 in the last part of the game?). I don't want to spoil the ending so I won't, but I will address the "incoherence" some people claim the game's story is guilty of. I am pretty sure that the curators that made that claim were either skipping through all the dialogue, or just refuse to acknowledge that a team of devs outside of the United States can make a compelling, unique, and deeply original story. Or maybe game journalists are all ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, I think that's most likely.This game is not appealing to the same crowds that find the Fallout or Metro games appealing, and I think that the reason for that is in the fantasies and idealized situations the game constructs for the player. It really does give you the sensation of being inna woods with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ soviet guns that jam all the time fighting hostile creatures and violently entrepreneurial bandits. You also get the neat sensation of collecting artifacts for science, and doing so under the constant oppression of the military and rival paramilitary factions that seemingly have no scientific aims. While in this debut title, there is no explicit faction-joining for the player, you do participate and witness the war for these radioactive artifacts, and it absolutely informs your player-choices that do in fact yield wildly different endings to the game--bad endings if you're a lazy and stupid player that doesn't read dialogue. I have beaten this game 3 times now I think? I'll never be able to eat ♥♥♥♥♥♥ spam knock-offs again without thinking about my misadventures in the zone scrounging for artifacts, assassinating corrupt military commanders and bandits, and drinking a dozen handles of vodka to make the radiation sickness go away. If you're intrigued play it and get hooked and maybe you'll pick up Clear Sky and Call of Pripyat which I'll review at some point.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is a great game. One of my favorites. I've been told modding it makes it the most fun, but I haven't done that yet.STALKER is has some bugs, silly voice acting (some characters only have one line and will repeat it every time you come into view: google "Get out of here stalker", or "I said come in, don't stand there"), but overall it's a great game.Similiarities and differences: STALKER is most similar to Metro: 2033, probably because they are some of the same people who made it. It is not very similar to Fallout 3, other than the large world (Fallout 3 is much larger) but there is no level system, no experience points. Just reputation with factions, which basically means "Did you kill any Duty members? Did you kill any Freedom members?" since these are the only real factions in the game which don't initially hate you.Mechanics: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is an exploration based game, if I had to call it something. The world is filled with anomalies that hurt you as you stand near. Throwing a bolt in the direction of one will activate it, showing you where it is. Expensive "artifacts" will fall out of them sometimes, and they will have various effects on your character. For instance, there is one that increases health regeneration but decreases bullet defense, and all other defense. It is terrible. There is also my favorite, Moonlight, which increases Endurance and decreases electrical defense.Endurance is the system of sprinting, carrying things, etc. If you are over-encumbered, and you walk places, your endurance will slowly go down. If you sprint, it will instantly go down. Having an endurance boosting artifact is one of the best things in the game because it gives endless sprinting when below 50 KG and longer sprinting above that. You cannot carry very much and must be very careful with inventory management. Side-missions will reward artifacts and special weaponry. They have a time limit. One set of side missions unlocks the "true" ending, you should save multiple times in the end of the game to ensure you get that, and look up how to unlock these side missions before going into Chernobyl. The storyline has you going from different areas into the game, until you get to the top of Army Warehouses, which is the end-game area. The shooting mechanics are very nice. Everyone, including you, has low health. Guns are inaccurate, damaging, and have bullet drop. Headshots are very powerful and can lead to a quick death, which makes this game hard for you too. There are many different guns and armors, many different bullet types. Rifles, Grenade Revolvers, Handguns, SMGs, shotguns, gauss gun, rocket launcher, sniper rifles. You can equip one major weapon and one pistol at the same time. To switch them out, you need to go into inventory. I love this game and it has a great open-world exploration aspect of it. Anomalies, bandits, mutants, and monolith are your enemies and the zone watches your fights.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Don't mind hour count. Had this as a physical copy, in the first place, way before Steam.This game is the pinnacle of post apocalyptic games. Pure survival. Constantly low ammo, low medicines, broken armour and weapons, and a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of spooky enemies everywhere. You can also perish for not eating or drinking, not to mention radiation. And not to mention gravitational/eletromagnetic anomalies you'll stumble into while running for your life, or searching for radioactive artifacts, that will either way kill you hopelessly. Everytime you leave your safe haven to start a quest, it feels like a true adventure... and you're never sure you'll be back in one piece on the first try. Most of the time, you won't. Be ready to cry, to yell, to pray, to hunt down bandits in the darkness, to spray your last AK magazine towards invisible tentacle-faced abominations in order to desperately try to save your life, to drink ♥♥♥♥♥ons of vodka, and most importantly, to cheeki breeki.10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												You are a S.T.A.L.K.E.R.One of the many mercenaries throughout Chernobyl that hunt artifacts formed by radioactive anomalies that do impossible things. Such as absorbing radiation, increasing resistances, granting health generation, or giving you near infinite stamina.These artifacts are sought out after by scientists and stalkers alike, and can fetch large quantities of money, making the zone a goldmine for anyone brave enough to traverse its dangerously unforgiving atmosphere.The game feels much more RPG than FPS, because every time you wield a gun it feels like an inaccurate wet noodle with a crooked barrel, while all your stalker friends, neutrals, and enemies have perfect laser beam accuracy and can take a clip to the face and live, while you get pinned to the ground dead at mach 10 if a stray bullet so much as brushes past your cheek. Even the illusive sniper rifles are weirdly inaccurate, and yes I know what bullet falloff and spread is, but this is ridiculous.If you can get used to the gunplay, it provides a satisfying experience once you consistently take down enemies, watch them flop to the ground, loot all their corpses, and waddle back to the shop to pawn it all.So S.T.A.L.K.E.R, get questing, killing mutants, shooting dudes, collecting artifacts, exploring creepy corridors, and taking in the sights of the hazardous deathtrap that is the zone.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2012
												Talk about a game with immersion - Having played S.T.A.L.K.E.R. SOC on retail disk countless times and then regretably selling it, I jumped at the chance to pick up the Steam version cheap on Ebay.You play as the "Marked One" and your travels will take you across the vast wasteland of the Zone near the Chernobyl NCP in the Ukraine.  This open ended blended RPG FPS will keep you plenty occupied with enough playtime to log countless hours.  There are a number of quests and side missions to partake in or just venture the Zone and kill mutants and search for artifiacts if you please - this i what I do sometimes to kill time and play around in the world.. just to enjoy its menacing atmosphere.The immersion and atmosphere is deliciuosly unique and the Stalker series is my fav regarding a creepy feeling.  I use the "Complete" mod available at artistpavel.com and it intensifies the atmosFEAR and graphics as well as does a complete overhaul of the game for a more stable experience.  Real time weather and day/night cycles are a treat to behold.  Sound and Music is great with eerie/spooky ambience throughout, gun effects are realistic.The graphics look stunning for portraying the grislt world of the zone which is a treacherous, darkly beautiful radioactive wasteland.  For as big as the game is the world looks fantastic and considering its a few years old.This is a hard game (my opionion) and I think is designed toward a more die hard PC player - it is not run and gun - you will die plenty.  The A.I. is tuff and smart - dodge and cover is there motto.   The first time you encounter a controller watch out - one of my favorite enemies ever.  Nearly half my friends list already has this gem, so they know a great game when they see it.Good hunting Stalker.  ✔Recommended

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												The king of suspense and post apocalypse genre. Granted its not exactly post apocalypse since the world has not been destroyed just...Chernobyl but thats beside the point since the game still gives of that feeling. Now to the game itself. It doesn't hold your hand right from the start and you can easily die on the first mission if you don't plan properly. Firefights are not a walk in the park and you need to be very careful unless you like reloading saves since you didn't notice the guy hiding behind the car. This game also allows the player to customize their loadout and make sure they have enough healthkits and food for when its needed...as well as vodka since it can remove radiation...apparently. Now everything wants to kill you in the game including the environment. Ontop of this be prepared to♥♥♥♥♥♥your pants since this game does horror well. You can go through 6 rooms in a building and then as you are leaving you hear a noise and well...something bad is in the building with you and it wants to meet you.To sum up, it a game which you will love if you enjoy a challange, a time sink, amazing enviroments and the genre itself.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R Shadow of Chernobyl is an elder russian game which is a post-apocalyptic, "open-world"-ish FPS game. (no this is not a fallout wannabe, even though at first glance it seems to be)This game it not perfect, nor that beautiful, and there are bugs and errors.But why am I then recommending this game? 'cause nothing is perfect, young padawan.The quality of the game gets highly increased if you mod the game, I did only play with weight mods, so I can bear a ton XD but there are lots of other quite interesting mods out there.Lets firstly take the "killers" of this game.- The game can crash a lot for some people, for me it was a very few times, there can be weird errors here and there but nothing that can't be fixed either with a reload, restart or just by ignoring it.- It is an old game, it is from 2007, so the grafic is only okay, not ugly but not pretty, and it is a russian game, I am not against russians gamedevelopers, they have created truly unique games like the stalker franchies, the hard truck apocalypse franchies and lots more. But it is wellknown that there can be a lot of bugs, luckily this one only has a few.- Better agrosystem. You can, if you snipe friendly target, kill them and if killed by one shot, you will therefore not be attracting agro to you, therefore you can kill all of your allies and loot them if you want to and still be ally with their fraction.- without any doubt there is missing a little bit of more detailed landscaping, more weapons, maybe a little more work on the plot and other small things. (not that the game is missing a lot on these things) Then there is the sunshines of this game- If you like a game which you can set to a hard difficulty, then this game is for you. You cannot be rambo in this game, not on higher difficulty, and if you choose to remove your sight of your weapon, then it gets a hell lot more fun(this game prepared me for killing floor to shoot without a weaponsight)- The atmosphere.... uuuhhh that is the one reason I really love this franchies, it has really caught this dark, lonely, chaotic and sometimes horrifying post apocalyptic atmosphere. It is not a game which "romantice" the post apocalyptic setting which many other post apocalyptic games do(not that it is bad, but it is great to get this realistic, "autentic" post apocalyptic atmosphere"- interesting monsters, they have been quite creative with some of their monsters, especially some of the rare ones did frighten the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me when I encountered them for the first time, especially the one which could affect your mind.- multiply endings! I didn't know this before I read about it, but this game has different endings! Of course now many games now at days, even FPS games, have different endings, but for me it is really a plus especially when this is an old game :) - Interesting univers/world/setting, lore and plot. Even though the plot wasn't the best in the world, there was still enough of mystery to this setting, that you wanted to explore more. - I love the real russian feel of the setting, because you really felt that you are in chernobyl because  the dialouge is in english with a heavy lovely Russian accent, then the NPCs talked russian to one another while you are walking by. But I have to say, I am a big sucker for the Russian language. :P so that is why I have this as a proSo yeah is this game better than fallout? No, especially not this one which is the first one in this franchies, go look for the newer installments, they are a lot better than this one. But if you have been playing through all fallout games and still crave for a postapocalyptic world, then this series brings another perspective and alternative setting(because it is not the whole world, only the closed world of chernobyl which are the setting)And yeah it is recommended to mod it(just like fallout) :)

This game will rock your socks and pack an amazing graphical package even for a game made in 2007! This game was groundbreaking in it's time, and it's hard to believe (Okay, well, except for engine bugs. it's not like source.) It's an old game. TRY VANILLA BEFORE SPRINKLES.] This game's really quite better than the other two, in my opinion. Please, If you like fallout NV and are a bit upset with how 4 turned out, Try this game, at least once. If you don't like it, you can complain to me. But I bet you'll like it for one reason or another.EDIT:I have racked up over 600 hours of this game, (12/2/13) making it nearly surpass my most played game (Mabinogi, 1500+hrs) in at least half the time. 												This game is really really unique and good. It feels realistic and hard, it trully is a challenge (it may be the second hardest game ive ever played)While the graphics arent really the best, theyre not half bad either. The map is huge, the variety of human enemies and mutants is also a nice addition to the game, the soundtrack and level design are really good, and best of all, the atmosphere is simply amazing. The game feels scary to the surface, but the underground levels are truly the horror aspect of this game. In addition to all this, there are a lot of side quests that you can do and equipment to collect, so the replayability is really strong in this one. I like the weapons, which there are a lot, and also the physics.I believe this game truly requires skill, and I recommend it to anyone who is a fan of the first person shooter, horror and RPG genres and is looking for a challengeStay cheeki breeki

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												Let everything that's been planned come true. Let them believe. And let them have a laugh at their passions. Because what they call passion actually is not some emotional energy, but just the friction between their souls and the outside world. And most important, let them believe in themselves. Let them be helpless like children, because weakness is a great thing, and strength is nothing. When a man is just born, he is weak and flexible. When he dies, he is hard and insensitive. When a tree is growing, it's tender and pliant. But when it's dry and hard, it dies. Hardness and strength are death's companions. Pliancy and weakness are expressions of the freshness of being. Because what has hardened will never win.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												STALKER is a little slow-paced for an FPS, but it does a great job of conveying the bleak and dangerous nature of the Zone. It raises some interesting questions and points about how people perceive a catastrophic event - to most it's a tragedy, but to some it's an opportunity. One thing I would have liked to be explored is how the player character reacts to waking up with no memories and with his only direction being to kill a man. Would he do so unquestioningly, or would he resist? But that's a question for another time. Overall, STALKER is an excellently atmospheric open-world game where the realism augments the feel instead of getting in the way.Full review here: http://postlaunch.blogspot.ca/2012/07/stalker-shadow-of-chernobyl.html

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												I wish I had the box so I could ♥♥♥♥ing burn it. I'm not saying it's all bad, but man, it will frustrate you. You're basically a ♥♥♥♥ing postman for most of the game, buuut you can't carry much. Oh, and all those working vehicles? Can't drive em, even though the cut scene SHOWS YOU DRIVING. But no, you can't do that. So, the first time you drag a corpse filled with guns and ammo and junk to sell so you can get some decent armour is fun enough. The second is a drag and you'll likely never do it again. The weight limit is a burden on your ♥♥♥♥ing life, and not just ingame life, I am talking your life. Your time. You are forced to carry a bunch of♥♥♥♥♥♥that you will need. Like, you know, guns, ammo, body armour. All that♥♥♥♥♥♥comes to about 34kg. But oh, you want some medkits, bandages, food and vodka (you need it) well that♥♥♥♥♥♥weighs 10-15kg. I spent most of the game at 45kg, constantly worrying how I'll maintain my stamina for a gun fight or to run back to finish a mission. Then I finally got it right at 34kg. How's the combat? The AI is ♥♥♥♥ing good but your weapons are♥♥♥♥♥♥and poorly accurate. You'll die a lot. Headshots are the way to go, but even on Stalker difficulty, the enemy are far more accurate than you are and will waste you. You think this place is not populated? You're wrong. For a radiated hell zone there sure are a lot of people around and a lot of them want you dead. Too many humans, too many damn mutant dogs and not enough actual mutants. I had fun with this game for a couple of days but I can't ♥♥♥♥ing stand it anymore. Worth checking out if you like hard games or think you're hardcore. I'd recommend it only to see what it's about and let you make up your own mind. Maybe with some mods it will come to life but I don't have time to ♥♥♥♥ myself with barbed wire.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2013
												This is the single most terrifying game I have ever played, and one of the most striking I have ever experienced. The sense of isolation, of total fear, is unmatched by anything except perhaps if you played System Shock as a child. A gun will keep you alive, but it cannot defend you from the anomalies, the radiation, the hunger. It cannot penetrate the darkness for you. It cannot be a friend, a confidant, or an ally. All you have is yourself, and man has made his own personal hell in the Zone. Coupled with mods to alleviate the worst of the bugs (and what game of ambition and vision has been anything but buggy?), I rate this as one of the most compelling experiences I've ever had in gaming memory, even six years after its release.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												First and foremost, because I would like to point this out first, because most of the people reading this probably will not want to read the whole massive explanation as to why I like this game. So to summarize, first, this game is an incredibly excellent game that suffers from some bugs and semi-regular crashes, but you can get unoffical patches and mods that help fix that a little bit. I gotta point out though, this game can potentially be balls-to-the-wall hard. So... Expect to play this game methodically, and not rushing through Call of Duty style hoping you won't get hosed down will bullets or surrounded by mutants and mauled to death. Because, spoiler alert, you will. And now, on to the big explanation!S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl is a game ahead of its time. Running off of a system where you need to conserve bullets, monitor your weapons' and armor's conditions, and be very conservative with materials. All of this is mostly thanks to the weight system. In most games that incorporate a weight system, like Elder Scrolls titles and Fallout games, ammunition (Usually) weighs nothing. Not in S.T.A.L.K.E.R., no, in S.T.A.L.K.E.R., bullets weigh a devent amount. So this brings an interesting system to the fore. In most games, I would have main firearms, one as my preferred gun, and the other as my backup, and load up on ammo for both of those. You can do that in S.T.A.L.K.E.R., but it's not optimal. Rather, you should probably just load up on ammo for your main weapons (Pistol and assault weapon), otherwise you'll be over-encumbered.S.T.A.L.K.E.R. also has a bleeding system. If you get shot in a non-vital spot, you bleed, and you should bandage up or you're gonna slowly bleed out. If it's a lesser wound, you don't need to worry about it, it won't bleed much. It's color coded, if it's red, you'll bleed out if you don't treat it, if it's green, it'll most likely heal in a moment or two. If it's yellow, it'll heal, it will just take a while, and you're probably better off bandaging it. This is the first game (Regarding it's time of release, in 2007) that I have seen a game make the bleeding system pertain to enemy AI as well. You hit and enemy with a few shots to the chest, he'll probably either die in a few moments, or curl up on the ground and eventually die like that. It's still very impressive.Everything about the weapons, armor, and gameplay, generally is extremely impressive. But that doesn't mean I don't have my gripes with the game. There are a few problems: A: this game can be buggy as♥♥♥♥♥♥ F6 oddly is the default quick save button. I set it to F5, becuase that's what it is in most games. That button is your friend. Use it a lot.B: I feel that a lot of the mutants take waaaaaaaay too mant rounds to put down. Unless you manage to hit them in the head, which is hard. Hell, even the blind dogs take like, at least a clip and a half from my Vintar BC to drop if I don't hit them in theh ead. There's a point where it starts to feel ridiculous, considering that this game pretty much forces you to ration off your ammo supplies.C: This game has an INSANE difficulty jump at the end of the game. It would be fine, if it didn't break all the rules that this game makes you obey. It forces you to move fast, and to act fast, while not dying. Up until that point, you essentially have to take everything slow and planned out. This ending just... It threw me off.---- Quick save is your friend. Remember this. ----Anyway, altogether, this game is awesome. There's a whole lot to do in it, between the warring factions, Duty and Freedom, and the side missions, there's a surprising lot to do. I would strongly suggest picking this game up if you haven't yet, and pick upt the STALKER: Complete mod for Shadow of Chernobyl. Makes it look a lot better, and tends to fix a lot of the issues the game has.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												Lets get some things out of the way -this game is not a twich shooter its gunplay is more similar to arma than CoD (which may be a dealbreaker for some)-you are slow and lumbering plus the lack of fast travel makes going back and forth between quests somewhat boring and monotonous -without spoiling anything the ending came out of nowhere (I was halfway expecting to be pulled back into the game after the credits)-there is no skills progression and base level weapons are still effective at end game if used properly -there are odd difficulty spikes when the rng nature of openents weapons and equipment rolls against you -game is not fully voiced in english (understandable given its Ukrainian developers-enemy AI has dificulty tracking moving targets (you can really hit them while running so its not game breaking)-you will die... alot (F6 quicksave F7 load last save)with those points out of the way I would like to say why I recomend this game-the skill based gunplay feels intuitive and fun -game is dufficult and unforgiving but fair-game builds up tension like nothing youve ever seen due to its fantastic lighting and sound design -I like to think of myself as being hard to scare but this game manages to -HEADSOTS ARE INSAKILL (for you and enemy keep that in mind when your questioning why you got oneshoted)-interesting faction and npc relationship system with every npc in game (shoot out a bandits legs but let him live and that same guy might save you in the future unless he gets eaten by wild dogs)-game will let you fail quests (essential ones will have to be completed some other way(branching?))-randomized unique weapons (you will more then likely main a autosniper that uses pistol ammo if you find one like I did(didnt make sense but I rolled with it))-this game will make you make tough decisions (spent 15 mins deciding weither i needed an rpg with one shot or my ammo for my main weapon(dont you ♥♥♥♥ing judge me!!!))

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												The word that can best describe this game is 'gritty'.I've beat it twice now, which makes me barely an amateur. The first time I didn't invest into the story and barely scrapped by the (suddenly very difficult) end game area. I didn't see it much more than an FPS with more stats to worry about, so I uninstalled it.Years later I gave it another try, but instead invested more into the story and gameplay, and I ended up really liking what the game did offer. STALKER definitely offers a unique 'gritty' experience that many other games won't ever aim for. Its a neat cross between something you would see in a more realistic tactical shooter, but has some of the exploration elements that you would see in more open-world games. Definitely worth checking out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6
												In short:This is my favourite game of all time! It has one of the best stories and atmosphere ever seen in a video game, especially for a first person shooter.Progression:You will notice that the first couple missions will seem kinda dull, boring or slow; keep up the patience the game might have weak start but has an amazing middle and end.Gameplay:Unlike most fps games this one has a survival feel attached to it, you will have an inventory to manage, weapons and ammo to collect, artifacts to investigate, acquiring better equipment and a fight against your hunger and thirst.Story (No Spoilers):You have one job, kill a person named Strelok. He's a legend to some of the people but you are going to find him. The greatest problem is the place you are in, the so called "Zone" a more apocaliptic version of chernobyl than in real life.As you progress you learn the strange things that have been apening there: mysterious artifacts, mutants, military exploitation, horrific experiments, and much more...10/11Make every bullet count, join duty, screw freedom and GET OUT OF HERE STALKER!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												Stalker may be the crown-jewel of Slavic post-apocalyptic games, surpassing even Metro 2033. With beautiful environments, a haunting ambient soundtrack, and vicious monsters, Stalker sets a dark tone for this survival-horror shooter. However, you will find that, unlike Metro 2033, humans play as great as threat as the monsters, perhaps even more so depending on how you play. With dozens of weapons, quests, and characters, you will be well prepared to discover all of Chernobyl's secrets. What is more, compared to Western post-apocalyptic games such as Fallout, Stalker possesses a much deeper and more intense story, especially towards the end, when the truth is revealed. Normally I would never recommend mods for a game, but in this case, I believe that Stalker Complete is well worth it, removing/fixing multiple glitches, and thus contributing to a smoother game. Overall, despite the savage nature of the environment, one cannot help but be impressed with how beautifully the developers strung together the story and characters. Overall Score: 10/10

content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												Strongly recommended.I first bought the game media DVD days after it was relased and reached my region... however, due to various reasons, I could not play it until now... those reasons were mainly language barrier (not native English, or good English at that time), so I could not understand much of the game back then... also my first encounter of the bloodsucker :D it made me jump on my seat... (I'll never forget that moment :D), so I thought: this is not the right time to play this game...I kept it in the shelve collecting dust, ignoring it, and I thought I wasted my money on it...Now, I got it on steam, and finally I could understand English well, so I thought, why not give it a try and see what is this game really is?I installed the 3 games, and started with SoC 2 weeks ago, and I just finished it...This game is now my number one game and I loved every single moment of it while I was playing... I lived with the main character through every single corner and place of it, and I will not forget my time playing this game...I will replay it, and I will make different choices through the game, again and again... I will not get bored of it I'm sure of this...This game has everything, RPG (of course), action, horror, mysteries, stealth and sneaking, and even some drama...This series (the 3 games Shadow of Chernobyl, Clear Sky, and Call of Pripyat), made me feel really sad for that there will be no STALKER II of it... and I really hope that a day will come and I see this got a "II" after its name...I definately recommend this to every single gamer who want adventure and all types of game play mixed in 1 game...This should get more hype and more known over some "big" titles out there.

content:

												Ah, the infamous STALKER. Vaguely alluding to the Tarkovsky movie also titled Stalker. This game is gritty, has exploring, monster shooting, and radiation (look out...that radiation is coming right for us!) *dodges radiation* whew that was a close one!I do wish I could give more of a review; however one giant problem occurred in my 15 minutes of playing this game. I got motion sick. That right this game is one of 3 games thus far that makes me motion sick (along with Dead Island and Battlefield 3). In fact there is so much godamn head-bob to this game I believe the character is on crutches or possibly has a form of palsy. Take two steps and you violently shake your head back and forth. Upon further inspection, the forums are rife with mods that are said to reduce this puke inducing feature of the game. I however don’t think a game should need a "anti-retch" mod just to walk across the friggin room.

												This is by far my favourite game of all time. I must of bought the game in 2009. I remember the first time playing it, I almost gave up on it as i thought I would not like it. Within an hour or starting I was completely hooked and couldn't pry myself away from the screen. The storyline,visuals, sound and most importantly atmosphere is like no other game I have encountered, and still hasnt been surpassed to this day. It is scary enough to keep you on the edge of your seat and heart racing, but never makes you feel completely helpless like all the survival horror games. It will most likely leave you clinging onto your mouse and keyboard for dear life.The freedom this game gives is also very rewarding. I am not a fan of linear shooters such as metro 2033, so if you like a bit of exploring this is the game for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2013
												This is the single most terrifying game I have ever played, and one of the most striking I have ever experienced. The sense of isolation, of total fear, is unmatched by anything except perhaps if you played System Shock as a child. A gun will keep you alive, but it cannot defend you from the anomalies, the radiation, the hunger. It cannot penetrate the darkness for you. It cannot be a friend, a confidant, or an ally. All you have is yourself, and man has made his own personal hell in the Zone. Coupled with mods to alleviate the worst of the bugs (and what game of ambition and vision has been anything but buggy?), I rate this as one of the most compelling experiences I've ever had in gaming memory, even six years after its release.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Mutant mayhemThe STALKER games have a reputation for being tough, and it’s well-deserved -- this is probably the most challenging single-player game I’ve played. Both the open world and the AI are very unforgiving. There are constant dangers not just from the wide variety of enemies but also from high levels of radiation and strange spatial anomalies. The Zone is a large place and during the course of the game you get to visit a diverse range of environments and encounter many weird malevolent forces. The combat is always demanding and requires a good deal of strategic thinking given that you have to deal with other health-depleting factors at the same time. The story, although it does suffer from the usual lack of focus as a result of non-linear gameplay and some uninspiring side quests, is still reasonably strong and engaging. Graphically it’s quite impressive, although I should point out that I installed the STALKER Complete 2009 mod from the get-go, which (as I understand it) improves on the vanilla game in this area. It’s true that there are some annoying bugs, but they didn’t dampen my enjoyment of the game too much. And even though the weapons and armour deteriorate (a feature I’m not overly fond of) the speed with which this occurs is more realistic than in many RPGs so it didn’t bug me too much. Overall the game scores very highly for its outstanding atmosphere, which is one of the most engrossing, and idiosyncratic, that I’ve encountered. Highly recommended. 4/5

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												Shadow of Chernobyl is a fun and expansive game set in "The Zone", an area of Ukraine that was directly affected by the Chernobyl Plant disaster. With that out of the way, I'd like to get down to why this game is so incredible. Atmosphere. You wont find a game that pulls you in and holds you there quite like a Stalker game. The game has a way of simply including you in the zone, making you feel as if every encounter is life or death and the moments in between are a sweet breath of fresh air. I tell you, there's nothing like coming in from the clustering darkness to an old railway station after fighting off hordes of obnoxiously intelligent (and I'm being serious, STALKER ai is frightening to fight against, and is rumored to be able to complete the game on their own) bandits to find a group of fellow Stalkers and rookies huddled around a trashcan fire, speaking softly in Russian, knowing in here, around friends, just for tonight- You're safe.Shootouts are frequent and heart pounding. It's recommended you play on Master difficulty with the crosshairs disabled. You and your target are likely to go down in a few hits. As I said before, the Ai is frighteningly intelligent. They will actively move towards you if they can, flanking and moving from cover to cover, plunking shots all the while. This makes choosing your cover very important, and forces you to keep a close eye on who your fighting with. All too often I've damn near♥♥♥♥♥♥myself because I let a bandit come up behind me while I was trading shots with a few of his buddies in a run down far. Speaking of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ oneself, The Zone is not only populated with bandits, but monsters as well, all of them designed and built around fear.STALKER is an RPG of sorts. You've got an inventory system, weight system, you need to eat every so often, there's an economy, weapons and armor to pick from, factions and reputation- It's got it all. Will I tell you it's done well? Not all of it. Don't expect to level up or pick our perks. That can somewhat be accomplished by recovering artifacts, but it's certainly not the same. Still, that's no reason to not check out the game. STALKER in the end is a fun and terrifying game, one that makes you feel like a rugged post-apocalyptic Ukranian artifact hunter and full time bandit/creature slayer. Shadow of Chernobyl comes highly recommended, and once you've done a vanilla play through, there's an abundance of mods to try out. Then go on to pick up CS and Call of Pripyat. Good hunting, Stalkers.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												A hidden classic of a game that has all sorts of quirks, but so much charm that you can't find in most modern games. It was developed by a now defunct Ukranian studio that hardly advertised their new IP, and became a cult classic. It's hardcore, it's buggy, it's slavic as all hell, and it is glorious.For the more intuitive PC gamer, the XRay Engine is highly moddable and the mod scene for STALKER is large and incredibly high quality. A vanilla playthrough is always recommended for first-timers, but subsequent playthroughs are much better with mods, as you appreciate what the mods change after experiencing the genuinely oh-so-lovely horrors of vanilla.Gunplay is fun, voice actors laughably bad, and the story is surprisingly good with bits of lore from books, science fiction, and even inspirations from the real life Exclusion Zone. One of my most favorite games of all time with incredible replayability and modding potentional, and an early example of an indie game before indie games were the fad of the day. STALKER is not for everyone, and takes a special kind of mindset to love, but for those that connect with it, nothing else compares. It is a game of legend. Buy it and immerse yourself in the Cheeki Breeki.

Posted: June 25, 2016
												Kind of a blend of the old and new Fallout games, with a grittier, scaryier, and more difficult world.I warn you, this game may be frustratingly difficult sometimes in the early game. It takes some time to learn how to do well. And getting some better weapons helps too. That said, use cover. Aim for the head, or legs as most humans wear body armor of some kind. Body shots are next to worthless. Once you get used to how to survive and fight effectvely, the game really takes off. The setting is grim in a way that reminds me a lot of metro, and the isometric fallouts. The lore and information introduced in the game's encyclepedia is not only interesting but vitally useful as well. This is the ONLY game I've ever played where reading the ingame lore compendium or encyclepedia entries as they unlock is rewarding! Enemies are challenging and frighteing, especially when you encounter new mutants that you don't know much about. You have to be aware of your environment when fighting so you don't back-pedal into a lethal anomaly or radiation patch.Only 10 is hours in but I am loving the adventure of this game. It has kind of an old style charm, like morrowind, but is very viable as a modern game.

												This is a copy of my metracritic review (I gave 10 out of 10):This game is a fps with a small rpg element and takes place in the 'Zone' around Chernobyl where you have to do missions to progress in the story.The opinion of this game is often black or white: many people love it while others hate it. In the beginning it took me also hours before I could understand the concept. I almost abandoned it before I started to like and love it. The graphics are ok but the atmosphere (e.g. weather, sounds, lighting in caves) is extraordinary. A good example is the first underground mission in Agroprom, which is spooky as hell. Some drawbacks are bugs and crashes, lack of transportation, difficult shooting (i.e. aim for the head and be prepared to get killed with 1 shot) and learning curve in the beginning.Despite its flaws I consider this is as the best game of the past 10 year.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R Shadow of Chernobyl is a single player, survival horror, open world, RPG. It is set in the year 2012 six years after the second CNPP explosion in what is none as The Zone of Alienation. The 60 Kilometer Exclusionusion Zone established around the CNPP. You are one of the many S.T.A.L.K.E.Rs that roam The Zone in search of valuable artifacts spawned by strange anomalies that seem to defy science. The game is quite difficult when you start off but as you progress you're given access to more powerful gear like tactical hazmat suits and exoskeletons. The controls are like any other FPS and easy to get the hang of. The survival aspect of the game is the need to eat, scavenge for medical supplies like anti-rad meds and bandages to stop bleeding, and searching for ammo and weapons. The atmosphere in the game is amazing. The first time I encountered a Bloodsucker, I nearly jumped out of my seat. One mission had me explore an abandoned laboratory that was crawling with mutants and ghosts. I couldn't go more than 10 feet without freezing from fear. I stood in one room for about five minutes straight, afraid to move and face whatever horrors lay deep within. Like most RPGs, there are side missions. They're okay for the most part. But after a while it gets a little repetitive with most missions being, go and kill this bandit, or go destroy a pack of mutants. But the rewards make it worth your time. There's a large number of weapons available in the game but most of them won't become accessible till you're at least halfway through the game. The game, minus side missions, should last you about a good 40 hours. But I highly recommend doing the side missions for extra money. Seeing as how most weapons and armor are expensive and trust me, you are gonna need good armor and weapons. Especially towards the end of the game. Now, the game does have a fair number of bugs. Most of which you can fix by installing mods like the S.T.A.L.K.E.R Complete mod which not only fixes bugs, but improves the graphics as well. The default graphics in the game are pretty decent for their time, but I still highly recommend playing with mods like Absolute Nature and Sharers Max. Final verdict: 9.5/10 The game is amazing unless you come across one of the rare game breaking bugs. My only other complaint with is that there wasn't much pressure to go out and explore. Most of the time I was simply going from mission to mission. Apart from those two problems, the game is phenomenal. I highly recommend playing it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												"KILL STRELOK"I never thought a sense of grinding dread would be a good thing in a game, but STALKER pulls off its atmosphere like no other game. Chernobyl's "Zone" is a bleak, dangerous land full of adventurers, opportunists, wonders, and mutants. Death is around every corner, and the game can be brutally hard at times. Still, the desire to explore this wasteland and meet the people and factions who call it home hooks you in. The story is nothing amazing, but it does make you want to know more about what's really going on.Playing the game is like an emotional rollercoaster. You'll be scared when exploring a derelict lab full of God-knows-what, relieved when you make it back safely to a friendly settlement, and happy when you have enough rubles to buy that shiny new gun from a trader. While technically not a post-apocalyptic game, STALKER has the best wasteland I've ever seen. One needs to be sharp and resourceful to make it in the Zone. Ammo has weight, and the carrying weight is low. You can't lug around twelve different guns and fifty thousand bullets. You pick up what's absolutely needed, maybe a thing or two that you can sell to a trader, and that is it. Sorry RPG-7, but you're not worth dropping a bunch of 5.45x39 ammunition nor medical supplies for. Knowing when to pick your fights is key, as every engagement has you using valuable ammo and meds, neither of which you seem to have enough of. Even with the best weapons and armor in the game, the Zone can still take your life before you know it.I would recommend first playing SoC with the Zone Reclamation Project mod which fixes many bugs in the vanilla game. Also, a mod that allows you to repair weapons/armor would be handy. STALKER SoC features unique weapons/armor and item degradation, but no way to repair them in the vanilla game. There's graphics mods as well if the vanilla game looks too dated. After that, go crazy. STALKER has more total conversion mods than any other game I've seen. It's like a different game every time you play. Also look into the expansions, Clear Sky and Call of Pripyat, which further refine and build upon the experience in this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												NOTICE: This review is on the original (vanilla) version of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. which excludes all mods. ==================Editorial Notes: One of by far the best FPS/RPG games I've ever own, was at first a little hesitant about this style. It has very odd controls and the AI is a laughable joke at easy settings but get incredibly difficult in harder/master difficulty (learn to duck and run when they reload). I'll be straight honest it is by far one of my favorite games to play when you have time to kill, just the missions alone can spend roughly 10+ hours if you really go above and beyond the beaten path and investigate nearly everything possible. A few Easter eggs can be found which I thought was rather clever but more importantly is the factions that act as you biggest pain the butt but the source of your jobs as a murderous psychopath. Each time I replay my game I try to use a different weapon that I rarely use, or a subset of weapons that I deemed unworthy to best myself and train in the hardest way possible (i.e. take a pistol or knife and kill a: snork, bloodsucker, any military officer) and even getting semi-creative with the use of surroundings.I will admit that the AI is very old and outdated meaning that they go by the line-of-sight controls. If they see an enemy they'll attack via line-of-sight and will gain a foothold by literally going straight even if that means going into a: fireplace, anomaly, or direct line of friendly fire (which in return get mad at you). AI also have two settings for accuracy, either they trained in the clone troopers training base or became solid-snake that trained with Agent 47's agency which ultimately depends on the difficulty you have it set to. Word of advice, rely solely on F6 && F7 your two newly formed friends of the trade.Pros: + Fun and interesting gameplay that stands against older games+ Can be rather challenging even during a 'weapon-free' zone; certain missions can leave you with an complex scenario where you can either go in guns blazing like Rambo or be like Sam Fisher and sneak your way in.+ Able to 'peak' around corners for some very unique firefights, AI can also assist in firefights (just watch for friendly-fire).+ Certain areas/zones have eerie soundtracks that even to this creation of this review, has a creepy factor that makes you watch your back.+ Open world; once you have certain missions completed or can pay off the right people.+ Different factions can ultimately change the gameplay; each having their own perks respectfully. (Duty = weapons, Freedom = Armor, STALKER = 'Monay Monay Monay....who needed Monay?')+ Semi-stealth; there is a stealth factor to the game as in if its dark enough enemies will have a harder time detecting you while you sneak. Whereas if you were to walk into a bush everyone including their mother will hear you thus alerting them to your presence. [Silence weapons are silent, if you get a kill it will be a silent unless they had line-of-sight on that target].Cons:- AI; as said before they will follow the path of the least resistance, even if that means walking into a anomaly or your line of fire. Some AI are even clueless as to where to go sometimes and will watch your movement until nearly everyone is dead in that area or they'll aimbot the next available unit even if its behind walls.- Controls; some of the controls are a little wonky. To access your PDA, press P. To check status of active task, press TAB. To go nearly prone, press CTRL + Shift (whilst using WASD and peaking corners). Some of the motions are a little clumsy, especially when getting shot at and needing to heal but fear that the moment you let go of the mouse you will literally run smack-dab into a bandit.- Difficulty; Can be easy as pie one minute then the next you are in the middle of one heck of a firefight with no clear visual of where that sniper is and "BAM" you see the text "You Are Dead" in harder settings. The harder you go the more accurate the enemy becomes, thus meaning that AK's can quite literally kill you in 2-3 hits even with a SEVA/Exoskeleton suit. - Buggy/Glitchy; Like most games there are bugs, but this game has quite a number of them (most are actually funny to see and do not really hinder the game performance). Situations such as side-missions can be tedious especially when you have to attack a group of military outside of Agroprom Research Institute by the zone load area and one of the military officers goes way behind the loading zone thus you cannot kill them but they can attack you. Certain areas have a weird NPC spawn area (wild territories) where friends or foe can literally spawn above you. Some of the more funnier glitches is using an explosive barrel near NPC's and watch them run into the fireplace and die.- Loading Areas; certain areas will have a 'loading' area to render the next part of the game. This can be very annoying when being chased and you 'load' into the next area but since you ran before the load you will waste your entire stamina and now your character cannot run away from what was hunting you down (i.e. running from the dogs in the bar area) You can theoretically bypass a few of them by going into a different part of the world but does not work for all.- Stealth; Like I said before there is a stealth factor but its very odd. You have to get a kill with a silent weapon (guns with silencer or a knife) whist being undetected or seen from an enemy. You have a visual bar that will show if you've been seen but it doesn't work part of the time, long distance firefights are the way to go if stealth is the objective.==================Conclusion: I really love this game with a passion! Even though that it was outdated and old, and a clumsy control but it rivals with Call of Pripyat and in general is a lot of fun to explore the different options that you couldn't do the game before. It's a fun game to have if you like FPS/RPG games and is by far one game that I love to use with mods (L.U.R.K. and the complete pack are fun to use). The replay ability is unheard of because you can replay the game but different NPC's will be used in different areas so where enemies might be wont spawn there till later or earlier in game, it has a random factor that always makes it more fun to snipe people out in full stealth and watch them squirm in their boots. Score: 8.5/10TL;DR version:* Wake up in room with bald guy while maintaining coolness factor.* Get gun from dead guy's body, wipe blood off face, stroke knife like a psychopath.* Run into military outpost, kill everyone with worst pistol in-game.* Shoot blind dog in face with AK-47, watch it skimper away as it holds hind leg up.* Almost shoot friend thinking was a bandit, shot them anyway, stole loot and ran off before their friends arrived.* Peek around corner in bar, greeted "I said don't just stand there, come in" multiple times.* Get told to "get out of here stalker", joined the Ukrainian-gladiator arena for money.* Peek around boxes in arena, see enemy stalker at end of arena.* Sneak up like Sam Fisher to enemy.* Peak around another boxes to spot enemy stalker, walks out in front of me, shoots my face.* You are dead, cry as i didn't quicksave.Would replay to crap my pants and get shot in face again. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												This game is awesome!! It is like a mature, more serious version of Fallout (though admittedly not as intricate, it's not really an RPG at all). The biggest point in this games favour is the immersion. After an hour I really got wrapped up in the whole world here. It really makes you feel like a loner in a desolate land where everyone is struggling by against bizarre and mysterious forces. Even little things like... hearing the distant cries of animals, the sounds of gun fights somewhere far off, a group of survivors just sitting around the campfire, chatting and playing guitar. It really adds to the immersion!The missions are somewhat varied. You don't feel bored really. Some missions (in the labs) are really some of the best ever, giving a feeling of survival horror or like the Shalebridge Crade from Thief 3. The locations are all memorable and no two are comparable. The gun play is decent enough though you can get killed pretty easily so this requires much more caution. There's some good chances to customize your load out (though not to Fallout levels).As for negatives... it could use a fast travel system like Skyrim. The map is huge and some missions mean travelling one side to the other regularly. Also, in a game where immersion is so evident I'd have expected to do more reading/listening to reports and notes left by other survivors. Some people hate that but I think in this game, if well done, really would've added to it.NOTE: there is also a big modding community for this game. Search for the Stalker Complete series. There is a "Complete" mod for each Stalker game. I am currently playing the vanilla version and it plays fine but have a look at the mod.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl is one of the most atmospheric FPS games ever made. SoC has the deepest and the most well wrote scripts of all the titles from the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series. One of SoC's main features is exploring small, but fairly realistic open world environments where SoC allows the player several choices as how to approach various situations in SoC. SoC also has the boon of being very replayable, as well as offer expensive mod content title thanks to SoCs robust community of modders. You can expect everything from new weapons and locations to full story conversions with SoC mods.SoC as well as other titles from the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series in general do have a lot of issues with bugs, various problems with the xray engine that the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games run on, and manual installations for mods which may not be for all potential players. But once you get used to frequent saving, and learning how to optimize SoC most SoC players will have a title they will look forward to continuing to coming back again and again.

Posted: September 11, 2013
												Truly an awesome game.  There's so much to do, and with the additional mods, it brings even more. For a game made in 2007, the graphics are pretty damn good.  The voice acting is a little sub-par, but to be honest, it makes the game a bit less serious and lets me enjoy it a bit more.Also there's mutants, anomalies, artifacts, and a trove of weapons.  But all of that can be discussed at a later date. For now, JUST PLAY THE DAMN THING.For first playthough, either Vanilla or Complete. This is the standard experience. Mandatory for everyone.For second playthough, either LURK or Autumn Aurora. Adds content, like weapons and armors.For third playthough, Oblivion Lost or ELITE mod. Adds moar content, like vehicles, anomalies, and artifacts, and humour.For fourth playthough, Priboi story or STALKERSOUP. Adds the most content like maps, main stories, and everything else.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												A hidden classic of a game that has all sorts of quirks, but so much charm that you can't find in most modern games. It was developed by a now defunct Ukranian studio that hardly advertised their new IP, and became a cult classic. It's hardcore, it's buggy, it's slavic as all hell, and it is glorious.For the more intuitive PC gamer, the XRay Engine is highly moddable and the mod scene for STALKER is large and incredibly high quality. A vanilla playthrough is always recommended for first-timers, but subsequent playthroughs are much better with mods, as you appreciate what the mods change after experiencing the genuinely oh-so-lovely horrors of vanilla.Gunplay is fun, voice actors laughably bad, and the story is surprisingly good with bits of lore from books, science fiction, and even inspirations from the real life Exclusion Zone. One of my most favorite games of all time with incredible replayability and modding potentional, and an early example of an indie game before indie games were the fad of the day. STALKER is not for everyone, and takes a special kind of mindset to love, but for those that connect with it, nothing else compares. It is a game of legend. Buy it and immerse yourself in the Cheeki Breeki.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I'm a sucker for post apocalyptic games / films and S.T.A.L.K.E.R. doesn't disappoint. The Russian zone has a fantastic, immersive and creepy atmosphere that really needs to be experienced to be appreciated. You get that wonder of what's around the next corner, what's in that ruined building or what's across that field of dead grass, but do you proceed or take a break? This game has a lot going for it... nice graphics, various quests, dynamic weather, night and day cycles, many weapons and mutated monsters, plus you can always have a shot of vodka. ;)  If you do buy S.T.A.L.K.E.R., there's a great mod that adds a lot to the whole experience called Stalker Complete (new textures, sounds music, bug fixes, AI fixes, ragdoll physics, etc...). All that and you can save at any time. Damned straight. Now get in the zone comrade! :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R remains to be the only game that I play which has FPS combat, for a multitude of reasons. S.T.A.L.K.E.R: Shadow of Chernobyl is an RPG set in the post-apocalyptic grounds of radiation-filled Chernobyl, where S.T.A.L.K.E.R's roam and reign in this wild west of mutants and Russians in gas masks. This oldie remains captivating to me because of this one, simple thing: It was crafted with care. Hell, the designers went INTO CHERNOBYL and modeled parts of the game after what they saw.Shadow of Chernobyl is a game built on atmosphere. Ho-lee♥♥♥♥♥♥ atmosphere is extremely present. From the way the lighting is done, to the wind effects, to the echoes of mutated animals crying out in the fields, to the eerie trance of quiet music beneath the whoosh of wind blowing by you as you trek through a field, bleeding and tired from an encounter... It really feels like what the developpers intended, which is that you're struggling to survive in Chernobyl with what you can find. Without adding legitimate "horror aspects," S.T.A.L.K.E.R developped a tinge of scariness with the excessive ammount of eerie that drives home the point it was going for. The combat engine is relatively simplistic, but it's satisfying. The damage frame makes cover actually necessary to outlast a longer fight, therefore making the lean function actually useful. The noise and visibility system added to the game also gives you the choice to go in stealthily or half-cocked, and also makes it that much more realistic; other people can HEAR YOU SNEAKING if you're sloppy, and wandering around with a flashlight will give away your position to anything that wants to kill you. Combine this system with angry russians, a gas mask, and some creepy torn up towns, and you've got S.T.A.L.K.E.R.Honestly, I'd pick this over Fallout any day of the week. I'd recommend this game to ANYONE.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2011
												Surprisingly dated graphics, and a few sizable bugs, but, despite these, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is still an Acronym...And a decent Game. Scary in places, terrifying in others, and incredibly action-packed in the rest. Made of several, inter-connected Free-Roaming Environments, this Game has quite a few things to see and do. Lots of weapons and weapon accessories, with plenty of monsters and mutants to use them on, this game is quite fun. An engaging, open-ended storyline that'll pit you against your nightmares, mutants and the millitary, you'll have to be fast and smart to overcome the obstacles in your way...Oh, and it helps if you speak Russian-despite the best efforts of the game's designers, in-game NPCs shout out things in russian during combat, important things to. Also, in-game chat has numerous mis-translations: Attic and Basement are commonly mistranslated sending you to completly the wrong floor, etc. Despite these bugs, it's a game well-worth playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Kind of a blend of the old and new Fallout games, with a grittier, scaryier, and more difficult world.I warn you, this game may be frustratingly difficult sometimes in the early game. It takes some time to learn how to do well. And getting some better weapons helps too. That said, use cover. Aim for the head, or legs as most humans wear body armor of some kind. Body shots are next to worthless. Once you get used to how to survive and fight effectvely, the game really takes off. The setting is grim in a way that reminds me a lot of metro, and the isometric fallouts. The lore and information introduced in the game's encyclepedia is not only interesting but vitally useful as well. This is the ONLY game I've ever played where reading the ingame lore compendium or encyclepedia entries as they unlock is rewarding! Enemies are challenging and frighteing, especially when you encounter new mutants that you don't know much about. You have to be aware of your environment when fighting so you don't back-pedal into a lethal anomaly or radiation patch.Only 10 is hours in but I am loving the adventure of this game. It has kind of an old style charm, like morrowind, but is very viable as a modern game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												I absolutely adore this game. For whatever reason it was one of my earliest Steam purchases, and really set a precedent for me. I'm probably one of the few people left that plays this game without mods/vanilla, and I'm always hesitant to install them. This game was my Dark Souls many years earlier. It is brutal and unforgiving and really takes an understanding of what is happening around you so that you can eventually feel like you are actually a powerful force in the world you inhabit and deserve to be as such. Hauntingly beatiful and deathly terrifying, I'd recommend this game to anyone who enjoys difficult atmospheric shooters (think early Metro 2033/Last Light with more outdoors settings). It has been a long time since I've had to learn and pay attention as much in a game as in this one, and I'll forever revel in it as it holds a special place in my heart. The following games advance in different directions but still afford notice, I've only played its prequel and not the sequel so I can't make particular recommendations there. If you like what you've heard here, and want to pick up an extremely interesting game that it would be hard to spend more than $20 on, heed my advice and go for it8/10
