content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Captures Slav culture in the most uniquely earnest way I can think of. You'll be fighting for life and death in the midst of an irradiated, paranormal wasteland against punks in adidas trackpants. The game has an atmosphere unlike any other. Sitting alongside other stalkers by a campfire in the dark under an idle guitar is, in my opinion, as immersive as video games can get. 1/15/17 edit; replaying the game on master. I recommend playing through on highest difficulty. Weapon accuracy improves.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is probably the most overrated game I've ever played. It's broken, unfinished, untested, unbalanced, and hard for all the wrong reasons. The last few hours of this game, a one way trip to a giant uninteractive level 10x the size of any before it, are laughably attrocious. When you get to pripyat, you'll notice it's already bigger than the entire game preceding it, unfortunately, unlike the rest of the game it's completely uninteractive and just filled with enemies. There's nothing to do but walk from one side to the other. Chernobyl itself is even worse. The entire rest of the game map would fit inside of Chernobyl, including pripyat which its even larger than. It's entirely empty, and you only need to walk through about 1/100th of it. About halfway through, a timer kicks in literally forcing you not to look around because they didn't finish the level. Fantastic. You can explore more of the facility in the best ending, but in total you can only explore the middle, top left corner and bottom right corners of the chernobyl map.Fans of this game will sell it as some genre-defining and perfect FPS-RPG, but I've played genre-defining and perfect FPS-RPGs, and this ain't one of them. The inventory management and artifact system doesn't hold up to System Shock. The role-playing doesn't hold up to Deus Ex. Gunplay is notably weaker than other realistic military shooters on PC, and guns are laughably innacurate. The endurance/food system is annoying, poorly thought out, and clearly an afterthought. This game's primary lasting influence is on the survival genre. Unfortunately, the game's survival experience is also laughably phoned in compared to later games in the genre, though I will give it credit for being an early attempt. That said, I don't really consider a game with a segmented 1-road south-to-north game map a true open-world survival game, and honestly think the survival aspects get in the way of an otherwise decent FPS-RPG experience.This is the general problem with Stalker. While its defenders swear that there's a great game under all the technical problems, the game is inherently flawed from a design perspective. A handful of levels, particularly late game, are outright awful. This doesn't mean its not good, but it holds it back from being the masterpiece that it is often claimed to be.This game is replete with some of the ♥♥♥♥♥iest, outdated mechanics I've ever seen in a modern game. Cover is worthless. Guns are completely innaccurate. Enemy accuracy varies ABSURDLY. Sometimes enemies will miss you from 10 feet away while you loot corpses taking no damage, other times getting within an enemies range at all will cause them to auto-hitscan whichever part of your body takes the most damage. I have a 200% health artifact, and I still occasionally go from full health to dead in less than an 1/8th of a second. Even 5 400% artifacts will not correct this, as all items that raise health raise bullet damage by 10% as well. On Master difficulty, where accuracy for enemies is at its highest, you'll still occasionally survive out in the open fights with 3+ late game enemies, to later be murded in less than a second by someone with an AK.Every single enemy encounter plays out exactly the same. You are tasked with going to an abandoned building and killing everyone. Often times, the AI will cause enemies to hide from you so well and for so long that you will believe they are simply spawning behind you. This will never stop happening. Oh, by the way, I hope you like radiation, because the devs used it to make sure every area has exactly one entrance and exit. In the early game, this is achieved via light radiation and your lack of a stalker suit. Late game, radiation is so heavy you'll need to stand around and wait for your health to respawn at times unless you literally grinded 10+ hypos and science medkits each. If you thought you'd get some emergent deus ex and Wolfenstein: New Order style choice in your raiding of buildings, its here, but only occasionally. Don't bother logically clearing rooms either, you will clear entire buildings, go outside to loot corpses for ammo, and be greeted with enemies running after you and instantly killing you having decided to run away from you until your back was turned. This happens particularly often in Pripyat and Chernobyl, which seem to literally spawn with 100s and 1000s of enemies respectively. I find myself saving more often in this game than I do even in DOS RPGs where spiders lurk behind every corner and wait to crit you to death. In those games, at least the spiders kill you slowly enough that you can heal. To be effective in stalker you will need to learn to apply medkits, hypos, and energy drinks via menu while running from things. Often.Making progress in this game is a matter of saving mid-fight constantly. If you even attempt to fight 3-5 troops without saving, you're making a huge mistake, because one of them will find a way to stand behind a bush his AI doesn't account for that you and the radar can't see through and slowly kill you from a mile away.This game has aspects I like, and I see why it's a cult game, but this is not a game everyone should play, nor is anyone missing out on anything if they choose not to play it. These are simple open-world mechanics that are done better, and less frustratingly, in even the oldest games in the genre such as Elder Scrolls Arena and Daggerfall. This is not some Dark Souls style "Hard, Broken and Frustrating, but also important to game design" game. In Dark Souls I can't walk off the map by simply drinking lots of estus the way I can abuse science medkits to do so here. Stalker is a callback to older, better games, in a period when not a lot were coming out. While this makes it good by the standards of the day, it can't compare to the best shooters of the late 90s or even now, and I find that a lot of the praise is solely there because, hey, at least it's not as boring as Gears of War.Reccomended, but only for hardcore gamers and fans of russia/ukraine/chernobyl history.8/10. There's a great game here, somewhere, if you can find it. The best ending is kinda cool if you can get it, and I reccommend you do if you want to explore some of the cooler (fully intended pun) parts of chernobyl.

number of helpful: 7 of 17 people (41%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21
												It's hard to give a yes to a game with so many clunky and unfun design flaws and bugs, but it's also hard to say no when the parts that do work end up being absolutely wonderful. The horribly nostalgic community paints a completely different picture than what I experienced and gave very wrong expectations for what the game actually is in 2017, it's incredibly hilarious watching them split when you ask about whether modding the game is a good idea, you get the purist who think it's normal for the average person to have 2 or 3 playthroughs that say do the first one vanilla and the second playthrough modded. You will get sensibile people suggesting you at least get the bug fix mods or use the overhaul complete mod.Clearly it's all preference, I can say for certain however if you are used to modern open world games of this genre, this game will feel like a rough draft, it's easy to get immersed in, but outside of that it doesn't hold much special to it, the story isn't good, the side quests are just simplistic as can be, and the exploration is rewarded sometimes with loot but you really won't find anything on the level of Fallout or Elder Scrolls.The combat is fairly realistic, but I found even from 10 feet away my gun was either missing or the NPCs don't react properly to getting shot in the chest, it'd be so much better if the game gave you more variety early on outside of a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ pistol or if the NPCs were more reactive to being shot, like being shot in the leg would cause limping for example, or shooting them in general caused reaction.It's buggy, and has some very obnoxious issues, like a HORRIBLE unchangable FOV and insane shakey cam, you can edit these away in a config file only to find the shadows will break too. You will also upon looking more into the game find various gameplay features not working because of how buggy the game is.So if you really want another game of this genre, it is a good experience for what it is, I highly suggest the STALKER complete mod, don't go some stupid purist route, don't torture yourself for it, you aren't missing anything except a game that aged like milk. Easily 4/10 unmodded, 7.5/10 modded.For 2007 maybe it'd been better but this is 2017 now.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												I've only played this game for fifteen hours and I can safely tell you: it's top notch.Story TellingYou play as the Marked One. An unnamed Stalker that is the lone survivor of a lightning strike that blew up a truck you were sleeping in before it rolled down a clif. You have two objectives: Repay the dept you owe the men who saved your life, and kill someone for some reason. Fortunately, despite having to pay off a dept, you still get paid for the work you do. However the only thing stoping you from going out and doing whatever you want are radiation zones and the excessive number of creatures and Stalkers trying to kill you. A Stalker is a person who resides in the Zone, usually for profit and more often than not hunting for Artifacts. The Zone is the name of Chernobyl after the nuclear disaster in 1986. An Artifact is an object of value that appears along side Anomolies. An Anomoly is a rip in time and space as a result of the nuclear disaster. The Story Telling is top notch.CombatThe combat amounts to trying to score a headshot using the world's jankiest, least accurate weaponry, because enemies will take three entire magazines from bodyshots before finally dying. Unfortunately this is the same for the player, so don't get shot in the head. The only exception is melee attacks which will also kill you instantly. This rule follows no matter what you or the enemy is wearing, exoskeletons are glorified radiation suits. ProTip: Accuracy is the only rating that matters, as anything short of a Sniper Rifle will miss the target at 10 meters. The combat is top notch.Virtual EconomyThis game takes place in the Zone, which is part of Russia, so you use Rubles. Keep in mind that one Soviet Ruble equates to 0.016 United States Dollars. This means that the most expensive item in the game, the Exoskeleton, is worth 3,120 United States Dollars. I should get me one of those. Problem is that they weren't mass produced because of the sheer cost to make. The Economy in Russia sucks. Trying to make money in this game either comes naturally, or is a giant pain in the rear. The player can only carry 50 kilograms of equipment before being weighed down and only 60 before being immobilized. Only carry what you need, money should only be really be made from Missions and selling Artifacts which usually weigh half a kilogram while being worth 1000 Rubles. Stuffing a corpse with 400 kilograms of gear and dragging it across the entire map is not fun. Most stuff you can buy is hidiously over-priced for what you can actually make anyways. The Virtual Economy in this game is top notch.GraphicsThis game was released in 2007. The Graphics are top notch.CommunityAsk a question and you'll get the most indirect answers possible, usually just being called a noob. They mostly just talk about mods and how to get them to work properly. The Community is top notch.Modding CommunityThe first mod I downloaded made my game crash on start-up. The second mod I downloaded did the exact same thing as the first mod except itstead of crashing my game on start-up it made in-game crashes much more common, a step in the right direction if you ask me. Eventually my game crashed so hard that all 12 of my save files became corrupted and unusuable. The mods for this game are top notch.ConclusionI'm glad I've invested 15 hours of my life and 520 Rubles on this game, because it's top notch.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Steam says I have played 4.3 hours of this game but it is well over 100 hours, probably over 200, counting playing this game before it arrived on Steam.This game has  - A great original story/journey - Great shooting mechanics with a lot of different weapons to choose from - all real world. - Great original, open world that is immersive and fun to explore, filled with mutants, monsters, bandits, soldiers, rogue factions, anomalies and more. What are anomalies you ask? They are fields scattered across the game, fields of nature and its laws bent. To a dangerous degree - Has an RPG-like inventory/space/weight/armor and weapons system and mission (quest) structure. - Furthermore, all missions are fun, varied and so unique that you probably haven't seen them in other games. The game isn't just filled with endless boring missions. Even if you're asked to kill X number of creatures, there will be a twist or a certain uniqueness to it. - Great occult atmosphere which will most likely make you question whether Chernobyl is "simply" mutated in a way that can be scientifically explained or if something supernatural is going on. I'm not telling you which - Do I even know?! - Has the potential to fright with it's lighting, monsters, dire situations and sometimes eerie sense of being alone in the       dark - Artifacts. Artifacts are (somewhat) rare equippable items that will grant you certain benefits, sometimes at a cost. They nicely spice up the game. - Mods!These points are what sprung to my mind. There are more, but this is what I could remember.I really urge you to try this game and its sequels out.Hope you enjoy the ride, nowGET out of here Stalker!

number of helpful: 3 of 14 people (21%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1
												I want to give this game a thumbs up. The music, world, the atmosphere, the story. Those things are all absolutely amazing. However, the game itself is essentially a guessing game of what happens first, you land a headshot or your enemy lands a shot anywhere on you. Usually it's the latter. I cannot in my right mind condone a game where you can shoot your enemies in the chest with a full clip at point blank range (Armor or not) and all they do is stagger for a moment, then proceed to shoot you once or twice and there goes your health (and this is regardless of what armor you yourself are wearing) All of that being thanks to amateurish development where you either play on low difficulty, and spend enough bullets on one enemy that repurposed could start a small war, or you play on master difficulty where what I wrote above is what you'll end up putting up with.A small example; I got to the end section of the game where you're running from warp to warp fighting Monolith with a FT-200M and a Sniper VLA courtesy my friends at Duty and an Exoskeleton. Throughout the entire section, I had more than one encounter with Monolith that took several bullets to the chest and kept moving to kill me in 1-3 shots, and would also somehow survive a shot to the head and keep standing.I keep hearing how immersive this game is, and it is, here and there, but those moments are immedietely broken when♥♥♥♥♥♥like that happens.Really, I wish there was a third review option between "Yes" and "No". I like it, but it tries my patience a little too much.

content:
Posted: April 22
												This game was released in mid 2000's and it shows. The game is challenging in respect to the enemies and the AI ability to flank you and avoid your fire - in most cases. in other cases, I see groups of elite enemy all together and I take them out with a single grenade. So pathing is probably buggy.  There are areas on the map where the PC freezes for 15 or more seconds - as if on the verge of crashing, but then becomes unfrozen as if nothing happens. Once you get used to the mechanics, its easy to shuttle sellable items. There are blue metal boxes all over, usually near a conflict area, and you can shuttle sellable items from one box to the other, slowly carrying the heap back to the trader and selling the loot. I have about 12 hours in the game and I think I have close to 25 grand. Crazy money for such a short period of play. Some times the game bugs out in the middle of a gun fight and then....your dead. Even if your using the best cover in the area and approaching the fight in a slow logical manner. The amount you can carry seems unbalanced. Typically i carry a rifle, a smg and a pistol. Then enough food for a decent adventure, and some healing packs and I am  above 35 of 50kg.  BEWARNED - some times the trader door will close and its a show stopper. The only effective way to get that door to reopen is to save the save at the top of the stairs. Then, hit #4 to put a grenade in your hand and head down as far as you can before the grenade is stored away. Throw the grenade towards the door of the trader. if successful, the door will either be all the way open, or partially open. simply push it completely open with your body. if the grenade toss didnt work, simply reload that save and try again.When you kill an enemy some times its really hard to determine where his main weapn landed. Most of the weapons on the ground look very flat and undefined.the map is nothing more than some crude symbols in a box. Your actually a white dot moving in a direction, with other dots on the map. It will take some getting used to to understand what the hell this radar style map does for you. the PDA style effect does help some, but if the hud/radar was a bit more refined, it would make the game play alot easier to decipher.This was recommended by a friend. I am more into a coop survival style game play. This game is OK, but its definately far from a main staple for me. I'll play this thing occasinally, but its not my cup of tea.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												The game is fine and aged pretty gracefully gameplay wise. Guns after overcoming the awful early game arsenal feel good and the environment really make you feel immersed in this destroyed, radiated wasteland.However this game just falls the ♥♥♥♥ apart in what it calls difficulty in the late game. Didn't bring the tankiest armor, 50 medkits and best anti radiation artifacts with you to the last few hours of the game? Well you're♥♥♥♥♥♥out of luck then, friend! The last few areas of the game are a gauntlet of bullet sponge enemies with high powered weapons that often enough will swarm you or attack you from several directions at once, rockets flying everywhere and radiation levels that require at least 1 rad resistance granting artifact on you (2 if you wish to be rad proof).For the sake of completion I forced myself to the end of the game only to be disappointed by getting a bad ending cause I had more money on me than the average cheeki breeki.Definitely will never go back to this game, which is a shame because I adore the environments of the game which obviously were crafted with a lot of love.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												I played this game for hours before I finally realized that I hated it more than I liked it. It has so many things I like. It's sordid, post-apocalyptic and there are russians. What's there not to like. But it's the way the game tries to fool me that get me so mad. First, it makes me believe I'm in an open world until I see the first "move to the next level?" which makes me painfully realize that I'm not really, then it's the way the game tries to be realistic in terms of combat, but I can shoot a guy in the head three times and he's still alive and kicking. And finally, it's that feeling that everything is without purpose. I go fetch some ducuments in some old camp or factory. There are soldiers, bandits, mutants, anomalies. I spend hours getting rid of them because my weapons hardly do any damage. I played this game for almost 20 hours until I realized that I just get frustrated because there's hardly any sense of achievement or progression. I run around and suddenly, when I reach a certain point, I advance to some next level where the story continues. It's a shame because there is so much potential in this game but it just feels unfinished. All I do is go to some place, avoid obstacles, shoot ennemies and go back to cash in some reward. It's not the worst game but after some time, it just gets boring as hell.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Summary: Get Call of Pripyat or Clear Sky and read about what happens on the wiki. (Pripyat is the best)Stalker Shadow of Chernobyl is a decent start to a game franchise but it as itself isn't really a fun game in my opinion, for starters the gunplay is really wonky as you need to pretty much get headshots or your out of luck (especially with the invincibility animations for every human enemy), It has a lot of bugs which I bet mods fix but still bugs are bad, everything isn't translated to English, there really isn't no thrill in artifact hunting and a few more things. I managed to "beat" the game in exactly 10 hours believe it or not and got one of the fake endings, what this means is that somewhere along the line I did the game a little out of order, or something bugged out, or I just didn't meet the right people. To me having a game mechanic like that isnt really my thing. (Would rather have 3 endings than 5 fake endings and 2 real endings that you have to look up a walk through to find.)This game exists between a open world game and a linear game as in it has side quests like things which are alright but you don't really get any reward other than rubles and maybe one of the 4 common artifacts that are literally laying on the ground everywhere you look after the first area.There are a bunch more things you can rip from the game but it does it job well as being the first of the stalker franchise, thus at the time establishing an ip that has a cool setting. But in the end the game isn't that great and if you really wanted to play it I suggest getting a big mod to fix the bugs and some other things.        All else just skip the game, go to clear sky or call of Pripyat and read about what happens on the wiki because even so I still don't understand some parts because I feel as the game forced me to get a "fake" ending and if I didn't know better then I would of  assumed that it was a real one.If you were to force me at gun point to put a number at it I would say 3 or 4 /10 only because of the cheekie breekie.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												I guess your suppost to play this game with what is called the complete mod. That being said I did not. I think a game should be able to stand by itself and that mods should only add to an already great experience. I really wanted to like this game, and I am no fanboy. I only recently decided to give / series a try. It has a lot of potential and a lot of good things going for it. Never have I had a game produce such conflicting emotions in regards of love and hate. But in the end, the numerous; and I do mean numerous flaws, ruined my experience. I could write a list that would fill a page or two on just all the bad design choices and all the bugs that need to be fixed. that its a bit riduculous. Such things like Stealth in this game is so sensitive that its nigh impossible to use. Enemies see you instantly, and once one sees you the whole base sees you. Compounded with the bug that allows enemies to sometimes see and shoot you through walls makes it double worthless. Sometimes I would load into a new area and find that I spawned in the middle of 5 to 6 enemies with shotguns. Guess what you die. And you will die alot in this game. Almost as bad as dark souls, but most of the deaths in this game feel undeserving. You fail not because its genuinly hard, but because you rolled the dice wrong. You can be shooting and using cover effectively and taking out 5, 6, 7 guys with no problem and then you barely pop your head around a corner and boom headshot your dead. or that guy you didn't notice with a shotgun flank you from behind. Guess what shotgun instantly kill you at close range at the eariler parts of the game. I could still list many many more problems. Such as the knife is useless and when you shoot opponets and make them stagger (a temporary stun) Instead of gonig 'oh good I can reload or can quickly kill the staggered enemy', Well you can't, because for reasons unknown enemies are invulnable to damage while staggered and shooting them then only wastes bullets.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												This game starts with lots of promise, and tries to do many different things, unfortunately failing to deliver most of them.It tries to introduce RPG elements, with weapon and armour stats, but then offers no character customisation or advancement whatsoever.Tries to offer a compelling story, but then most missions do not advance it, or have anything to do with it at all. Why would I risk my life to help these guys and just have some ammunition in return? Just so I can use those bullets to help more random guys and... have more ammunition in return again?Tries to be a "survival sim", with the need of food and rest, but the simulation feels forced and artificial when you notice that you can only sleep in your own bedroll. There are perfect beds and sofas in encampments, but your character doesn't know how to use them.Also, you can run forever at something like 40 Mph, without breaking a sweat.It tries to be a survival horror, of course, with monsters creeping out of the shadows and whatnot, but also gives you a magic PDA that knows where all the monsters are, tells you who is friendly and who is an enemy, where all the loot is hidden and so on.Also tries to be an "open world", but you soon realise that the world is tiny and surrounded by 2ft tall barbed wire that for some weird reason you cannot jump across.Also, the fact that you can run at incredible speeds without ever getting tired means that you can run from one side of the map to the other literally in seconds.But there are other aspects that completely ruined my gaming experience:Everything respawns. This means no sense of accomplishment: good job clearing out that bandit camp... except that you didn't, because here are the same bandits again.Non-hostile NPCs respawn too, so I didn't care to save them. Why risk my life? Let them die, loot their bodies and wait for them to respawn the day after.I have already mentioned how missions have no purpose in regards to the story, but they also make no sense per-se: a bloke in a full kevlar suit, wielding an automatic rifle and granades asks me to kill some bandits. Me?! When I only have a knife and a tiny pistol...Everything is resolved by shooting. I've done some 20 missions in the few hours I've spent with this game, and every single one of them was about shooting somehting or someone.Bandits? Shoot them. Retrieve stolen goods? Shoot more bandits. Find the hidden suitcase (hidden?! it's marked on my map!!!), shoot some mutants. Dirty dishes? Shoot them.A glorified shooter that promises to offer more, but only dlivers mindless gunfights.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												This game... is broken. It feels like it should have been a pretty decent game, but... it just isn't. the way that projectiles work is horribly broken. at no point in time should i have to use an entire shotgun magazine to kill one enemy two feet away from my face. there isn't any real way to take accurate shots, because there isn't any feedback coming to the player to correct their aim. the auto fire feels more accurate that single shot, which is really irritating. i  use half a magazine (on single fire)toward an enemy- without killing him!- that guns me down in a ten round burst. Speaking of AI, the hitreg on them is God-awful. the hitboxes feel like they aren't even on the enemy half the time, and i die more from shooting at the enemy model than where the hitbox actually is. One of the more irritating things in this game is the "zombies" which are really just like all other AI, except they soak up bullets and try to shoot you to death. that gets excruciatingly irritating, wasting ammo on them.the AI also aren't even remotely tactical. they will walk toward you and blow you away even if  you are checking all corners and keeping an eye on your surroundings. On top of this, radiation becomes a serious problem, especially without a hotkey for the anti-radiation drugs. Yet, oddly, an enemy can stand forever in a hot zone and never die from it.But, apparently, stairs are a player's saving grace in this game when dealing with radiation.The storyline is somewhat nonexistent, and i'd almost forgotten most of it by the time i had gotten to the end, and had been surprised by the ending cutscene. the multiple endings to the game was a nice touch,though. too bad there wasn't any real story to back it up, though.Now for the things that are good about this game.The weapon selection is great, with weapons such as the VSS Vintorez, MG36, USP .45, SVU, and other, more unique weapons like a Gauss rifle that can only kill with headshots (though it apparently does the most damage in the game).the trading system is good, and there  are some pretty nice things that can be gotten from it, and only certain traders can accept all types of goods. the inventory feels much smoother than DayZ, for example. the stamina mechanic is good, and the idea of having a carry limit (60kg) is another nice step toward realism. The best part about this game though, are the mods. this game can almost be compared to Minecraft for the amount of mods that make the game better or more interesting. Many things had been cut before this game's final release, and many mods add those things back in, such as the ability to drive vehicles, the P90, a minigun, etc. however, since its the base game i am reviewing, i can't really vouch for the game with mods installed.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
												This game has very poor mechanics. It has what I call "Mace Griffon" syndrome - basically wherein the AI instantly knows where you are, even if you're obscured by bushes or trees or even buildings. For a game that's supposed to be all about stealth, it's actually probably the worst stealth game i've ever played. I waited about a decade to play this game; all i ever heard about it was ranting and raving from everyone. Finally was bored enough to give it a shot. Well, honestly, even the original Far Cry is a better stealth game than this. Hell, even Sneak King is a better stealth game than this. Fallout 3, without VATS, has better FPS mechanics. So you're a stealth FPS, that has worse stealth mechanics than a promotional game made by Burger King, and you're a worse FPS than possibly *the* bar for crappy FPS mechanics (Fallout 3. Admit it; playing that game without VATS is torture)Literally the only redeaming factor about this game is the open world, and ability to murder the first group of people you're supposed to be helping one by one, in the shadows. However, I wouldn't recommend anyone play this game. Ever.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												This is for a pure vanilla run of the game. I can't speak to modded experiences. I intentionally chose vanilla cause I saw my buddy playing this game back when it came out and I myself really wanted to play it as well.Finally played it and well... It's a very overrated game. It has a lot of great ideas nothing works well, and some of them work against each other.The game is an open world FPS and works hard to give an open world RPG feel where item management and food management and running quests (you're supposed to use quests to get the good items) help you get the edge on your enemies. Really very excited in concept. The problem is the shooting is bad (even on master difficulty) and the story line is completely uninspiring and full of cliches. The art direction is initially exciting but that falls flat because its more or less all the same. The game becomes a chore. The terrible shooting and strict item management makes the first few hour and a half or so, when your guns are legit bad, punishing. A few hours afterwards you start to feel rewarded, but then the missions become longer fetch quests with more shooting and the facade drops. Your guns aren't bad-- the shooting is bad. The item management punishes and never rewards, and the story is the barest excuse for a long fetch quest.  Which is sad because the game has promise. It isn't enough of an RPG to compete with Fallout 3 and New Vegas. And it isn't anywhere near enough FPS to compete with Metro 2033 and Last Light. There really isn't any reason to play this game vanilla.

number of helpful: 2 of 22 people (9%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												....Ugh.It had some pretty immersive and fun parts, but I have so many complaints that it just nullifies it.For starters, it's a buggy mess of a game surprisingly.  The gameplay is incredibly clunky.  The monster AI is okay (since all they do is charge you), but the human AI is downright ret%rded, even for 2007 standards.  Sure, you can give me the whole faction system and alliances and all that, but the AI is so incredibly inept that I couldn't even bother with it.  The story is engaging, but the ending...Seriously?  The f%ck was that?  Felt pretty rushed if you asked me.  And no option to free roam after you beat it? Like a lot of RPGs, the beginning is the most difficult and challenging.  However as you progress through the game and get tons of money and the best gear you will DESTROY everything in your path.  And I hate that.  Oh, and that "open world" aspect of the game that I expected?  Wanting to explore the whole region without interruptions?  WRONG.  Perhaps this is my own fault for not looking into it.  If this is considered "open world", it is truly one of the smallest and most linear I've ever played. Oh, and enjoy those loading screens....A lot of them.I'm not saying the game is bad, it just didn't appeal to me as it did to others.  In my opinion, Fallout is the better alternative.

number of helpful: 2 of 22 people (9%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												This review/rant may be solely out of the rage I feel but its accurate non the less:Even in the easiest difficulty (novice) do I find this impossible to play. Unusual key bindings can likely be fixed, but that won't ever compensate for the fact that there is too many unlikable details that this game posseses. The weapons and ammunition in this game are literally useless. I became trapped in a two or three story building within less than two hours of playing and no matter how many manuveurs I pull and no matter how much ammunition I have, I am f***ed. I don't know if this is just unfortunate circumstance, but when hurt in battle, I will hide behind cover and nobody will show up for a multitude of seconds; they wait for you to open up your inventory to spawn back out and kill you. Yes, gameplay doesn't stop at checking your inventory, and you will die if you aren't unrealistically quick enough.The characters I've met so far are also boring. They all talk when you walk up to them, but after that you have to read their paragraphs; they don't read them for you. Textures and animations of characters are also primitive considering that this was released in 2007. All you do is run around doing favors for money and information. No interesting, out of the ordinary dialogue, and the storyline so far is dull and all I know of it is the short introduction sequence in the beginning which really doesn't explain very much to keep me interested. The fact that this game lacks auto save doesn't help its cause either.I'm not the best at gaming, and I mostly play for the storyline. It's not fair to compare games to different games of different series from different companies, but I must admit that games like Half-Life are much more playable and have a more interesting storyline than STALKER, and that's almost a decade older than STALKER.If you are more into easy but exciting combat accompanied by an appealing story, you've come to the wrong game. I got this game on sale, which is good because this in my humble opinion is definitely not worth its usual $20. I'm sure if I continued to play I would be more interested into the storyline, but the gameplay and combat just kills it for me. I bought the first STALKER only so that I can try it out before I buy the others. I'm glad I did because I have no interest into playing this game ever again.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												I brought this game when it was originally released but was too yound to understand the mechanics. Now I'm older and am more familiar with the different elements it throws together (RPG, action, narrative, survivial management). I was played the 2009 complete version (see the downloads section) which makes things look nicer and adds some good features to make backtracking less repetative. I can't reccommend this game at all. The action hasn't aged well at all and you die far far too easily. Ultimately you'll be hitting F6 (to save every few metres) and then F7 (to reload) because some enemy is tucked behind a corner, or spawns on top of you, or is simply way over powered. I had some good moments in this game but it doesn't introduce you the mechanics you need to understand at all and the story is buried in logs (which if you don't read the cutscenes make no sense). On the postiive side the enemies are well designed and look really grotesque/frightening.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												Let me start off by saying in no way do I support anyone buying this game. I bought it with the other two sequels in a bundle on Halloween for 60% off the price in 2016, and I really regret this purchase more than anything. I've not played the two sequels, I've played this game for only four hours tops, but here is why I refuse to be silent about this game and why it sucks.- The community is 50/50 good and evil; you'll often find many role player friendly types who will welcome new players and give you advice, others will♥♥♥♥♥♥all over you and will make you hate everyone who likes this game as they turn it into some elitist scumbag club.- The gameplay is broken, buggy, and intentionally designed to♥♥♥♥♥♥on you. The AI is borderline omnipresent and omniscient; stealth is apparently a big focus in this game but due to the AI being literal gods, it doesn't matter. They can see you across the map even if you're in a bush hiding, in total darkness/shadows, or hiding behind walls and all it takes is one hit to end your life or to get ten or more people swarming you. The higher the difficulty the "better the chances you have of a bullet hitting someone", as the difficulty scales up so does damage - but only for you. You'll die a lot, quick save a lot, quick load a lot, and find enemies some how auto-spawn in front of you or on top of you during these quick save/load sessions (I don't know if this is a bug but it sure isn't fun to save in a safe place then have enemies spawn right before your eyes in an empty room after loading). Enemies are virtually unable to miss you in terms of accuracy; you can't see them when they're in a bush but they can see you, and if you use stealth as I've said it doesn’t matter as they can see you no matter what. Headshots are the only way to kill most enemies and even then you will find enemies can (without armour mind you) take several magazines or shells to the face and simply walk it off. Some enemies can even teleport you to their location, paralyze you, hit you, teleport you BACK to your original location, then repeat until you die (you have no choice but to ride it out too) and all of this happens all at once while you're across the entire map between several walls.Tl;dr - Veterans say to increase the difficulty to help with bullet sponges, they also say that it gets better once your equipment improves - but it's all a lie. You will NOT have fun dealing with the extreme challenge in this game as the challenge is nothing but bad programming for a game made in the mid 2000's. Go buy a better game like Fallout 3 or NV and mod it if you want survival RPG/FPS fun, at least there you can mod the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of the games to make the enemies take proper damage…

												I really wanted to like this game, I love the premise. I've always been fascinated by Chernobyl and Pripyat. However, this game itself is very poorly designed. Gunplay is weak and unsatisfying, ammo is far too easy to find and plentiful for the atmosphere to be tense and for it to feel like true survival, and my biggest complaint, the "open world" isn't even open; it's littered with semi-invisble walls known as "anomalies" that kill you if you touch them. I'm sure at some point later on you unlock an ability that lets you pass through them, but in a game like this, being free to go wherever you want at the very beginning of the game is part of the appeal. Heck, even some quest objectives were blocked by these walls, and I had to navigate my way around them to get to where I was SUPPOSED to go. It was not engaging, tense, open, or fun. I sadly refunded, as I loved the setting, but the abysmal gameplay and world design were too bad for me to look past.

number of helpful: 51 of 145 people (35%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												This game is basically an FPS RPG set in an alternate reality after a second Chernobyl event, that creates a highly irradiated area known as THE ZONE filled with artifacts (loot), anomalies (radioactive traps), and mutants (MUTANTS).  I have been playing this game since 2007, on again, off again, and I am finally ready to say I can not rightfully recommend this game, even though I've logged 98 (semi)enjoyable hours playing it.  This game is the kind of game that reminded me why I love games, and why I hate some of them.For the longest time, I couldn't really tell what I was playing.  It seems like an FPS with a run-of-the-mill post apocalypse amnesia story, and I began to play it as an FPS shooter, hoarding everything, and taking every mission I can, like I was playing RAGE or something.  This is not how you play S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games.  It is an RPG that you have to take your time with in order to immerse yourself in the game's story.  You must understand different social influences, environmental threats, and simple survival needs the zone might present to you in order to react to your situations properly.  Most importantly, you can not hoard loot. If you like Infinity Engine inventories (e.g. Baldur's Gate) where inventory management is an entirely different game, you will LOVE the inventory management in S.T.A.L.K.E.R.The environments are beautiful for a 2007 engine, and surprisingly great even today, especially with mods like S.T.A.L.K.E.R. complete.  The loot is good, the story is fascinating, and the monsters are scary.  The game blends between open-world exploration and survival horror corridors pretty fantastically.  You tell yourself one more mission, and then the sun is up.  This game will suck you in completely.  This is good, because stalker has a very intense pretty learning curve (as I discussed earlier) and basically requires that you play it in "hardcore" mode.  You are constantly negotiating between different environmental threats, and sudden mutant/bandit attacks.  Not only are there bandits that might attack you, but there are different factions with different goals for The Zone - the missions you accept and many of the actions you take will affect their attitudes towards you, potentially creating other threats.  The most mundane actions are life threatening in the brutal world of S.T.A.L.K.E.R.Why don't I love this game?  Well, remember how I said I've been playing since 2007 and I've logged 98 hours?  That's because this game is insanely glitchy.  I have run into numerous game breaking bugs that have forced me to start over.  It has a really good save menu, so if you don't use quicksave for days at a time (like I do) you'll be fine.  You can reload to a save point before when a friendly faction suddenly decides to shoot you in the face instead of paying for a mission for NO REASON AT ALL.  You won't have to accept the fact that your character is stuck in the wall now, and the game is anti-climatically over.  It's a shame, I can not get through this fantastically designed but poorly executed buggy game. It's one of the most refreshing games I've played in a long time.  It appeals to my old school PC Gamer side, and I love every bit of it - the game allows you to pick missions freely, explore the world an in open-fashion, and progress to the end at your own pace in an environment that is constantly engaging - I've just had that experience unplugged on me too many times.

number of helpful: 3 of 29 people (10%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												I'm changing my original review, although not changing the fact I do not reccommend this particular S.T.A.L.K.E.R.Pros:1) A pretty epic story2) Fun battle encounters3) Entertaining throughout the game.Cons:1) The constant rocking when walking takes serious getting used to & will most likely make you dizzy at first.2) Broken English and inaccurate subtitles are sometimes a minor hinderance.3) There's a serious issue with glitches. Mission glitches, Secret Stash glitches, enemy spawning glitches, & every now and them you'll get environmental glitches like getting permanantly stuck behind or inside and objector even falling through the ground entiriely.4) The moster AI leaves something to be desired (they are stupid).5) The saving, although relatively simple (Press ESC, click save, select save spot, confirm, then click return), it does ruin the fluidity of game-play when you have to save every 5-10min or risk losing all your progress. A simple quicksave key would have fixed this issue.6) Compared to other S.T.A.L.K.E.R games, there's a serious lack of weapons & modifications. In fact, the only mods you can do is add & remove scopes on a select few weapons & an undermount grenade launcher on even fewer weapons. There's also a supressor you can change onto any handgun.7) Death, you die, a lot! Specifically as you get closer to the end of the game, which frankly, just becomes irritating.Altogether this game is a conundrum to me, I did like playing the game, but I don't think I would reccomend this game anyways, simply because all of the  "Con"  factors & the fact that you have two better choices in the S.T.A.L.K.E.R series.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												This game is disgustingly bad unless you also install the free Stalker Complete mod available online. After installing Stalker Complete, the graphics are improved as well as the gameplay, but it appears to come with a bug that double-renders the game thus crippling the performance. I was seeing a nearly unplayable 10 FPS. When I switched to "static lighting" and re-zoned suddenly everything worked great, even dynamic lighting that was supposedly turned off (!), and I was then able to max every other setting and enjoy smooth-as-butter performance. Although Stalker Complete fixes some problems while adding others, there's a clear workaround that I just described. So why bother with Stalker Complete? Most notably it gets rid of the most hideous viewbob in FPS gaming. That viewbob alone kept me away from STALKER for years. Finally the title is at least playable. However, I cannot recommend this game due to head shots not always counting. Even at point blank, an AK to the head does not always result in a kill. You will take damage no matter how well you play, which results in you being a bottomless pit for medkits and ammo. It feels cheap for this reason. The one thing the game has going for it is level design, but I can't say it adds all of the ambiance and experience that I want from a game like this. You spend too much time shooting humans and taking medicine, but not enough time feeling any amount of fear.

number of helpful: 15 of 67 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												I put in alot of time in SoC, but I learned that I don't like this game. My problem isn't with what the game is trying to be, but the experience often ended up more annoying than fun.Instead of a full review, I will highlight bullet points of things I like or don't like of this game.+Atmosphere: The world is definitely dark and gritty, and exploration is haunting thanks to rabid mutant creatures, anomalies, and trigger happy factions. The overall sound design/ambience is pretty good for its time, but I was annoyed by some overly repeating sound effects.+World Design: The world design feels pretty good as it feels like it could exist and assets weren't so over used that the world wasn't believable. I'm not running in and out of the same buildings in different spots. In comparison to Ubisoft style open games, you don't have a ton of unnecessary fluff such as find all the relics or chests, do the time challenge missions, or find a tower to scope out an area.+Freedom:  While there are definitely story based "road blocks", but sections of the game world are seperated into relatively large open areas and most building complexes/towns that you need to "attack" may offer alernate ways to enter and provide a chance a stealth.=Equipment based progression: I miss an RPG style system, but it works well here as you progressively get better gear through your adventures. Admittedly, I've had to default back to the lowest tier AR and SMG due to ammo consumption in this game.-Looting: You have a large, Diablo-esque inventory, but you have limited space and little use for large amounts of cash a few hours into the game. You get clues from stashes regularly from corpses, but stashes often end up being a better place to store items since you have a limited weight.-Difficulty: I like a challenging game, and SOC is definitely hard. My problem is a combination of features that eventually annoyed me. Veteran difficulty was interesting because enemies can be killed quickly, but enemies always seem to have high accuracy, high damage threshold, have weapons that don't jam, and almost always are in groups. Meanwhile, my gun shoots all over the place, bullets ping off enemy armor, my rifles jam at the worst of times, and in the rare times I have AI support for missions, they're either Godlike or brain dead. I lowered the difficulty and apparently, doing that actually makes some bullets dissappear - seriously, read up about it. Also, many times in the game i've been able to kill goons with ease, just to get killed quickly out of nowhere with a shotgun or a guy who decided to have perfect accuracy while my gun jammed.  I've quickloaded in this game at a higher rate than any other game i've played.-AI Fail: In some cases, the AI is good and you can get in situations where you move around the map and confuse them. But in other cases, I've had them shoot through walls, know my exact location after evading them, or in one mission, not notice I shot a comrade with an unsilenced AK47 with in 10 fen of him. Escorts are a pain as they never sneak and will constantly run without stopping, unless there is a firefight, in which they will try to be the hero, even if they only have a weak pistol against an army of rifle wielders. Aren't I supposed to do the killing while you stay behind? And you can't give them commands either. The bad companion AI in Skyrim and New Vegas is better than this.-Glitches and annother annoyances: Many populated areas have NPCs that utter the same line or two constantly. Escort missions are terrible, where your escort runs head first into battle even though they desperately requested your help. A faction asked for my help with mutants from far away, and then killed them so fast before I could help me and called my useless. There's a glitch with dropping items in your inventory, which is awful when trying to get ammo out of guns and manage inventory weight while some enemy creeps up on you.My final straw was some mission where I had to retrieve something from a body. I spent so much ammo trying to kill zombies and wierd leaping enemies. These zombies have figured out to shoot, are nearly tanks, and have nearly as good accuracy as a normal person. I killed most of the enemies though, worked my self to a building corner to kill one more zombie. I turned the corner, worked my way to the zombie shooting at me and strafing behind cover. It met up with another zombie out of nowhere and both were clipping through each other, shooting me with perfect accuracy through solid cover, even though their guns weren't actually above said cover to hit me. They killed me, and the NPC I was working for was still greeting me with "Hello! Hello!", half a mile a way, through an enclosed building, that is shut with an airlock. I had enough, and funnily enough, that NPC was stuck saying is greeting the past 10 minutes while I was shooting and being shot at.I'm not compelled to bother with the other games in the series. I've got too big of a backlog and better games to play. However, SoC has an atmosphere, world design and challenge that many gamers crave.

number of helpful: 3 of 37 people (8%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												I'm greatly disappointed by this game. I've been waiting for a good sale for months, hyped by what I had read about an FPS open world survival game, and what I found is an earlier Fall Out: New Vegas minus VATS. Credit should go to this game for inspiring New Vegas, but that's it.It's neither open-world (or maybe it is, if you call the ability to roam the countryside with nothing to do in it "open-world"), nor survival (oh jeez, my hunger metter is low. I'll eat one of those canned whatevers that every enemy drops), and judging by the inability of my char to hit anything smaller than a truck from more than 10 meters away, I'm seriously in doubt about considering it an FPS.Not to mention the stupid fixation with making the enemies soak damage like if they were made of steel, most of the time shrugging off bullets while melting your face in a salvo.I hear that, if you manage to not get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off by random encounters against tons of enemies (to make up for the horrid AI) that depend more on your luck to hit and not be hit by enemies and your patience than on your skill, or by suddenly being shoot in the back of the head rigth while entering a new area, then you probably can find the classic choice between factions and whatnot. From what I've seen this far it's "this guys are neutral. Those guys are mad at you for no reason. Oh and those ones too. Go shoot them or something".The weapons found so far are boring, amounting to 3 types of samey pistols, a double-barreled shotgun, and 3 or 4 types of automatic rifles, which I call "mister spready", "spready junior" and "the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of spreadyfell", in honor to his lesser spreadiness. Seriously, it's more ammo efficient to just charge headfirst guns blazing than it is to carefully shoot at a distance. And you'll save time even if you have to reload the save once or twice.To summarize, I find this game barely enjoyable, and even if it turns out to have some hidden beauty later in the game, it does not convince me at all to keep playing and see for myself.Veredict: 5/10

												Do NOT buy this game or any of the games in the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series. I bought this on sale for $2.49. I can honestly say this is the worst ~$2.50 I have ever spent in my life. This counts in all aspects, not just gaming. I'm talking about when you lost money  in a vending machine, or decided to pay for rush processing on NewEgg, which you really didn't need. This game series surpasses all of your bad purchases in that price range. They spent so much time trying to make this game look great, but instead developed the clunkiest turd I have ever had the displeasure of passing through my bowels. Where do I start? Well for one, the game has the clunkiest shooting I have seen in a 21st century game. Duke Nukem 3D was honestly easier to shoot than this game. The sounds are garbage. This includes the dialogue, too. I think they hired the likes of voice actors like FPS Russia for the game's dialogue. "Get out of here, Stalker, " will forever plague my mind on how badly I was Rick Roll'd.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2011
												I've tried to play this game several times and always quit due to its slow story and boring side missions. This time I decided to play the main storyline all the way through. I was rewarded when the game finally started getting better around hours 3-4, but I questioned my persistence along the way. Unfortunately there are multiple endings based on your choices throughout the game and the choices I made ended up making a very poor ending to the game, explaining absolutely nothing.The open world shooter is very primitive by today's standards, but the foundations are solid. The atmosphere, environment, sounds, and FPS aspects are the game's major strengths, but the story is confusing due to its lack of depth on top of weak RPG elements. The AI is pretty tough often using cover, but they are also buggy.Some areas of the game seemed worth exploring more, but I don't think playing it a 2nd time through would make the experience any better. Pass this one up and go play Fallout 3.
